story_text: Company responses to BHRRC report - Just for show: Worker representation in Asia's garment sector and the role of fashion brands and employers - Business & Human Rights Resource Centre
response_text:
20 May 2024  

(By Email) 

Business & Human Rights Resource Centre 
London, UK 

Attn: BHRRC – Asia Desk 

Dear BHRRC, 

Response to BHRRC research on alternative worker representative structures 

Thank you for reaching out to adidas for our response on research BHRRC is currently conducting on the 
ways in which alternative worker representative structures, such as worker committees and company / 
“yellow” unions, undermine workers’ fundamental right to freedom of association and collective bargaining. 
As part of that research, BHRRC has canvassed the views of selected trade unions in Cambodia, including 
the Coalition of Cambodian Apparel Workers Democratic Union (C-CAWDU).   

C. CAWDAU is registered as a trade union in the Meng Da factory, which makes adidas footwear product. 
C.CAWDAU claim that there are too many competing trade unions in Meng Da that are under the influence 
of the factory, and that workers are left “confused as to where they should go to resolve issues”. 

Since 2010, a total of 17 trade unions have established themselves at Meng Da. These unions are registered 
with the Ministry of Labor and Vocational Training (MOLVT) and have continued to renew their mandates to 
represent their members in the factory. Based on the registration certification at MOLVT, we understand 
that C. CAWDAU was first established at Meng Da in December 2015 and currently represents some 3% of 
the workforce.  

Collectively,  the  17  active  unions  represent  approximate  2214  members,  or  50%  percent  of  the  total 
workforce  in  the  factory.  The  4  largest  unions  represent  some  1539  workers.  Based  on  our  own  direct 
monitoring  we  can  confirm  that  all  trade  unions leaders  who  had  sought  election  as  shop  stewards  (or 
assistant shop stewards) were freely elected by the workers at Meng Da. We have received no reports of 
manipulation  or  interference  with  that  process,  which  is  overseen  by  the  trade  unions,  the  factory 
management and the MOLVT. 

The elected shop stewards meet weekly and individually with Meng Da’s management team, which provides 
them with an opportunity to raise any issues of concern. They are also free, should they so wish, to raise 
grievances directly with the factory’s Human Resource (HR) Department. And indeed, we understand that 
C. CAWDAU has actively used this channel to raise issues on behalf of its members. HR has also established 
a  social  media  app  for  the  factory’s  unions,  to  enable  them  to  post  issues  to  HR  that  need  immediate 
attention. This is actively used by all the trade unions. 

Page 1 of 2 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Given the number of active trade unions in the factory, adidas has asked Meng Da to seek consensus and 
endorsement from each union - irrespective of their size - whenever there are any major changes in the 
workplace, i.e. with respect to workforce planning, overtime arrangements, etc. This is a practice that has 
been in place for many years and Meng Da has fully documented all such union endorsements.   

adidas has a social compliance team based in Cambodia, which regularly visits our suppliers’ factories and 
if any Meng Da registered union perceives that the factory is interfering with their trade union activities, 
the union can raise complaints directly with adidas. To date, we have received no such complaints from C. 
CAWDAU. 

With respect to worker complaints, there are various channels available at Meng Da and these have been 
communicated to the trade unions, to their members and to all workers. Those channels include raising a 
complaint directly with the HR department, or anonymously through the digital grievance app, or the more 
traditional suggestion boxes. If workers require support or representation, they can request the unions or 
shop stewards to act on their behalf, and they frequently do. 

If you have any additional questions, please feel free to contact us. 

Sincerely,  

William Anderson 
Vice President, Global 
Social & Environmental Affairs  

Page 2 of 2

Responded To: Company responses to BHRRC report - Just for show: Worker representation in Asia's garment sector and the role of fashion brands and employers

response_text:
H&M Group response to BHRRC_May 2024 

For H&M group freedom of association and collective bargaining are key factors for improving wages 
and working conditions in our supply chain. We expect our suppliers to sign and comply with our 
Sustainability Commitment which clearly states that these rights are recognized and respected.  

To support strengthened industrial relations, we have signed a global framework agreement with 
IndustriAll and IF Metal. National Monitoring Committees (NMCs) consisting of H&M Group 
employees and local trade union representatives implement the agreement in Bangladesh, 
Cambodia, India, Indonesia and Türkiye. In 2023, the NMCs covered more than 820,000 workers in 
our tier 1 supply chain and workers raised 23 issues with these committees, 21 of which were 
resolved. The majority of issues raised related to compensation and benefits, as well as severance 
payment.  

Together with 19 other global brands, we’ve partnered with IndustriALL to form ACT (Action, 
Collaboration, Transformation). Our joint goal is to achieve living wages by supporting collective 
bargaining, freedom of association and responsible purchasing practices. ACT is operating in three key 
production countries Bangladesh, Cambodia and Türkiye. 

In 2023, 37% of our tier 1 factories had trade union representation. Additionally, bi-partite 
committees are mandatory by local labor law in the majority of production countries where we 
operate, including Bangladesh, Cambodia and Indonesia. In a recent update of the Better Work 
programme, the ILO cites well-functioning bipartite committees as part of stronger industrial relations 
that support better working conditions (ILO 2024). Our public supplier list includes the presence of 
trade unions and/or democratically elected worker representatives for factories. 

We take violations of freedom of association very seriously and we welcome any complaint on 
possible issues through the channel of our National Monitoring Committees (where present), directly 
with our teams on the ground or other channels or grievance mechanisms. 

Please find details on the specific cases shared by BHRRC below: 

Hung Wah, Cambodia 

We can confirm that Hung Wah (Cambodia) is an active supplier to H&M Group.  

According to the last report by Better Factories Cambodia (BFC), there are in fact 24 active trade 
unions at the facility, 4 of them are affiliates to IndustriAll. We acknowledge that this might be 
confusing for workers, but so far we have found no case, nor concern indicating that the rights to 
freedom of association and collective bargaining are undermined.   

The last BFC assessment was conducted in October 2023 and no violations with our minimum 
requirements nor with BFCs critical issues was found as shown in this public overview of findings. 
Within the area of industrial relations BFCs critical issues include workers right to freely from and join 
(or not to join) a union, no control of nor interference with union by management as well as no 
discrimination against workers based on union membership.  

 
 
 
 
 
 
 Dekko Design, Bangladesh 

We can confirm that Dekko Design (Bangladesh) is an active supplier to H&M Group. This case was 
raised through the ACT Interim Dispute Resolution Mechanism and we have been actively involved in 
resolving it through for example fact finding sessions and interviews of impacted workers, mediation 
role between the two parties (management and trade union) and follow up with factory management 
on the actions points agreed in meetings with the parties. In that process we collaborated with 
IndustriAll, their affiliate trade union BGIWF, factory management and other brands sourcing from 
Dekko Design and we are thankful to all stakeholders who contributed to that an agreement could be 
reached in the end.  Read more about this case here.  

PT Sai Apparel, Indonesia 

We can confirm that PT Sai Apparel, Indonesia is an active supplier to H&M Group.  

The last assessment by Better Work Indonesia was conducted in December 2023 and revealed 
indications of preferential treatment towards one union.  

We are actively involved in this case and our colleagues in Indonesia have been in direct contact with 
the trade union, the supplier and Better Work Indonesia to help resolve it. We have made it clear to 
the supplier that we expect them to uphold Freedom of Association and that discrimination based on 
union status is unacceptable. We encouraged them to continue to build a social dialogue between 
workers/unions and management in the factory, specifically to resolve any issue that may arise at the 
factory in good faith. We will continue to work on this issue with local stakeholders.  

We recognise that the risk of labour rights violations exists in all countries and across our value chain 
and we are very committed to assessing risks and thoroughly investigate when we hear of allegations 
and issues that should be addressed. One way to ensure access to remedy when violations occur are 
effective grievance mechanisms. We expect all our suppliers to have a grievance mechanism in place 
so that workers can raise a concern. 

In 2023 we updated our Labour Rights Survey, which monitors workplace dialogue and grievance 
mechanisms. More than 205,000 workers completed the worker survey which we combined with a 
selection of third party factory data (collected through HIGG FSLM). As a result, we have visibility of 
how effective factory grievance mechanisms are according to the UNGPs criteria. We are now 
working with our strategic suppliers to create tailored roadmaps designed to strengthen social 
dialogue and grievance mechanisms in the factories in order to improve access to remedy for 
workers.

Subject: response to BHRRC query on 16 August 2023 in relation to EACOP and Tilenga projects 

Dear BHRRC team,  

Following  your  email  dated  16  August  2023  inviting  TotalEnergies  to  comment  on  the  allegations 
mentioned in the two following articles:  

• 

• 

“Persecution: The prosecutor’s office is turned into a tool to harass locals for opposing land grabs 
to  give  way  to  the  oil  project  in  Mid-Western  Uganda”,  27  May  2023,  Witness  Radio: 
https://witnessradio.org/persecution-the-prosecutors-office-is-turned-into-a-tool-to-harass-
locals-for-opposing-land-grabs-to-give-way-to-the-oil-project-in-mid-western-uganda/ 

“Close to 20 local farmers are in jail for fighting for their land not to be taken by the East Africa 
Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP)”, 24 April 2023, Land Portal: 
https://www.landportal.org/node/113879 

Kindly find herewith our Company’s response:  

By  way  of  introduction,  we  remind  that  TotalEnergies  is  the  operator  of  the  upstream  oil  production 
project  Tilenga  through  its  subsidiary,  TotalEnergies  EP  Uganda  (TEPU),  and  it  is  also  the  majority 
shareholder in the East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP). On the other hand, EACOP Ltd. oversees the 
construction of the crude oil pipeline.  

Responding to your query, we’d like to state that the above press articles claim incidents occurring to 
human rights defenders and referring to events that are completely unrelated to our activities.  

Kindly refer to our arguments below: 

1.  The  villages  in  question  are  situated  several  kilometers  away  from  either  Tilenga  or  EACOP 
infrastructure. The land in question is not affected by the  projects and is not  part of the land 
acquisition programme. Additionally, none of the persons mentioned in the article are Tilenga 
or EACOP Project Affected Persons (i.e., persons whose assets or land are part of the projects 
land acquisition programme).   

2.  Moreover, neither  TEPU  and  EACOP Ltd  have  any  record of persons, NGOs or Human Rights 

Defenders raising concerns or grievances in relation to this land. 

3.  Further, neither of TEPU or EACOP Ltd work with an organisation called Magnum Security. 
4.  Nevertheless, we have sought clarification from the relevant authorities regarding the claims. 
We  understand  that  the  evictions  may  have  been  conducted  by  a  private  individual  who 
claimed that the evicted persons were occupying his land unlawfully.  

We would like to highlight that the land acquisition process undertaken by TEPU and EACOP Ltd respects 
local laws and regulations and is compliant with the International Financing Standards (IFS), including 
IFC Performance Standard 5 on land acquisition and involuntary resettlement.  

Finally, in line with TotalEnergies’ approach to respecting human rights  of any stakeholders including 
human  rights  defenders,  TEPU  recognizes  the  importance  of  protecting  human  rights  defenders and 
does not accept any threat or attack against those who peacefully defend and promote human rights in 
connection with its activities. (See the TEPU’s  Statement on Human Rights Defenders (HRD)). Also note 

 
 EACOP  Ltd’s  commitment  to  respecting  human  rights  in  all  its  activities  and  its  recognition  of  the 
important role of human rights defenders in promoting human rights (https://eacop.com/human-rights-
policy/). 

Yours sincerely,  

Sustainability and Climate team 

TotalEnergies

Attn: Business and Human Rights Resource Center 
Subject: Response to the rejoinder by Witness Radio Uganda dated 25 September 2023 

Dear Sir/ Madam,  

We take note of the rejoinder by Witness radio Uganda which affirms that TotalEnergies and its projects 
are  partly  responsible  for  the  forced  land  eviction  of  2,500  PAPs  and  Kapapi  community,  without 
compensation and without being offered alternative resettlement.  

Both TotalEnergies EP Uganda (TEPU) and EACOP Ltd maintain their earlier position that no land eviction 
activities have been carried out by or on behalf of TEPU or EACOP Ltd and none of the affected persons 
mentioned in the article are Tilenga or EACOP Project Affected Persons (PAPs).  

The  rejoinder  suggests  that  the  affected  people  come  from  the  villages  of  Kapapi,  Runga,  Waaki,  and 
Kiryatete which are mentioned in the RAP 4 report, and as a result, it attributes the evictions to the Tilenga 
and EACOP projects. We wish to clarify that the villages in question, notably Runga and Kiryatete, were 
initially identified during the planning phase as potential areas to be affected by the project and initial 
disclosure engagements took place. However, once project footprint had been fully mapped, it became 
apparent that the above villages would not be affected by the feeder pipelines as they are situated several 
kilometers  from  either  Tilenga  or  EACOP  infrastructure.  Consequently,  these  villages  were  kept  clear 
during construction and none of the persons mentioned in this article are either Tilenga or EACOP PAPs. 
Hence, there was no further engagement on the acquisition of the land in the said villages.  

It  is  therefore  misleading  to  suggest  that  TotalEnergies  and  its  projects  have  caused  or  are  partly 
responsible for evictions from land in which they have no footprint.   

We therefore invite you to correct this false assertion in the rejoinder. 

We would like to reiterate that the land acquisition process undertaken by both TEPU and EACOP Ltd 
respects  local  laws  and  regulations  and  is  compliant  with  international  standards.  Additionally,  the 
companies do not condone the use of threats, violence, or force in any of their activities.  

Kind regards,

response_text:
H&M Group response to BHHRC – 22.07.2024 

H&M Group takes any reports of alleged abuse in our supply chain very seriously and we always 
follow up as soon as such concerns are brought to our attention. 

We have a strong local presence in our sourcing markets, including Indonesia, which means we can 
build genuine partnerships with our suppliers and collaborate closely with them each day. 
Through our Sustainable Impact Partnership Programme (SIPP) we support our business partners to 
raise their environmental and social performance. We reward high-achieving 
and responsible suppliers with training opportunities and long-term contracts. In addition to that, as 
a founding member of ACT we have committed to responsible purchasing practices, which among 
other things includes a commitment to better planning and forecasting.   

As shared in our public supplier list, PT Sai Apparel is a supplier to H&M Group with two factories: 
one in Semarang City and a more recently built factory in Grobogan. The supplier is in the process of 
relocating the production from the factory in Semarang City to the unit in Grobogan which 
unfortunately will affect employees in the first factory. We are in a close dialogue with our supplier 
about their plan and we have made it clear that we expect them to engage in social dialogue 
throughout this process.  

In the end of 2023, the factory management and local trade union reached an agreement to ensure 
that permanent workers whose jobs will be affected and who do not want to relocate to the new 
production unit, receive the severance payments that they are entitled to. This agreement is covering 
almost 1500 employees and its implementation has been supervised by the local labor office.   

According to the supplier around 1400 former employees from the factory located in Semarang City 
are now working in the production unit in Grobogan (please note that we are not able to verify these 
data).  

ILO Better Work assessed the Semarang City factory and in their latest progress report (June 2024), 
stated that all previously outstanding issues in this regard have been resolved.  In addition to these 
third-party assessments, we continue to monitor the situation closely.

response_text:
Stuttgart, 14.08.2024 

INVITATION TO RESPOND TO BUSINESS & HUMAN RIGHTS RESOURCE CENTRE 

Dear Business & Human Rights Resource Centre, 

Thank you for reaching out to Mercedes-Benz. We would like to express our gratitude for the 
opportunity to provide comments on the allegations and to elaborate in more detail on some of 
the points you have raised. 

•  We are aware of the current case and take any hint very seriously. We are already in contact 
with the supplier and have pressed for the potential allegation to be clarified. Please be as-
sured that we will take appropriate action if allegations prove to be valid and verifiable. 
•  The Respect for and protection of human rights are of fundamental importance to Mer-

cedes-Benz. We are aware that there is the potential risk of human rights violations in cer-
tain supply chains and are therefore actively taking action against it. 

•  Mercedes-Benz seeks to ensure that its products contain only materials that have been 
mined and produced without violating human rights and environmental standards.  

•  Sustainability is the guiding principle of the Mercedes-Benz business strategy and thus the 
core of our entrepreneurial activities. This claim also characterizes the cooperation with our 
suppliers. We can only achieve the goal of a sustainable supply chain together with our part-
ners, with whom we work closely.  

•  Our supply chains are very complex. With tens of thousands direct suppliers and many more 
sub-suppliers, you have to proceed strategically and risk-based. With our Human Rights Re-
spect System (HRRS), we have developed a systematic approach for the prevention of hu-
man rights violations in our supply chains. It allows us to identify and avoid risks and possi-
ble negative effects of our business activities on the respect for human rights at an early 
stage. We have defined clear responsibilities and internal policies for the implementation of 
our risk-based management approach to the protection of human rights. We also manage 
this topic in compliance with globally applicable guidelines and reference frameworks. 
Where appropriate, we work together with selected partners and industry associations and 
continuously further develop our due diligence approach. For more information, click here.  
•  Besides our systemic risk-based approach, Mercedes-Benz Group AG requires its direct sup-
pliers to comply with the Responsible Sourcing Standards, to integrate them into their up-
stream value chains and to monitor compliance with these in their business processes and 
sphere of influence. The Responsible Sourcing Standards are derived from the requirements 
for human rights, environmental protection and business ethics, which Mercedes-Benz 
Group AG applies in its own business activities. They contain minimum requirements as a 
contractually binding prerequisite for business relationships with our suppliers. We encour-
age our suppliers to go beyond the minimum requirements and align with our supplemen-
tary expectation.  
More information: Responsible Sourcing Standards | Mercedes-Benz Supplier Portal 

Should you have any questions arising from our response, please feel free to contact us. We 
would appreciate if our answer were still taken into account for your newsletter. Please excuse 
the delayed response due to public holidays in Germany and resulting absences. 

Thank you very much! 

1

response_text:
Dear Business and Human Rights Resource Center: 

We have received your letter and also noted the article in question. We would like to 

clarify the following points regarding the accusations in the article: 

1.Regarding Community Relations 

(1) Regarding Land Permits 

The land acquisition and land use processes in Zeravshan strictly adhere to laws and 

regulations, including planning, application submission, village consultations, obtaining 

government approvals at all levels, and obtaining land rights certificates, all of which 

have been approved and documented. Our company has always adhered to the 

principle of voluntariness in the process of signing land sale or acquisition agreements 

with villagers, ensuring that all transactions take place in a fair and transparent 

environment. We have retained all signed contract texts and have paid agricultural 

losses and development compensation to the original land users based on legal 

frameworks and negotiations. Additionally, we have established a comprehensive 

community communication and grievance mechanism. Villagers can use this 

mechanism to request the company to meet their reasonable demands in case of 

disputes during the land permit acquisition process. 

(2) Regarding Community Investment Commitments 

The company has been fulfilling its obligations to develop Khumgaron Village as 

planned. Completed community investment projects include the restoration of a 4-

kilometer road between Khumgaron Village and Chorbog Village, the construction of a 

water pipeline worth 1.04 million somoni, the restoration of the No. 83 school in the 

village worth over 55,000 somoni, and the payment of a 2.7 million somoni guarantee.  

The company is committed to building good relationships with all surrounding 

communities to ensure that they benefit from the development of the mine. We have 

made investments in community traditional agriculture, specialty crop industry 

development, infrastructure construction, assistance to vulnerable groups, and 

education, health, culture, and sports facilities construction, with the company's 

investment in the community exceeding 13.28 million US dollars. 

2.Regarding Environmental Protection 

(1) Regarding the Impact on Surrounding Crops 

 
 
 Global warming and the drying up of the Aral Sea have had a widespread impact on the 

ecology of Central Asia, which is a well-known fact. In recent years, the black sand 

carried by the westerly winds has also affected the Zeravshan Valley, causing trees and 

crops to be covered in black ash, affecting the growth of crops and fruits. Upon learning 

of this situation, the company organized relevant training to help farmers cope with 

these natural phenomena. Farmers who have acquired knowledge and taken measures 

have successfully avoided the impact of black ash. In the future, the company will 

continue to provide training to community farmers to help them better cope with the 

challenges brought about by climate change. 

(2) Regarding Water Quality 

The accusation in the article about causing the death of a large number of fish and fines 

is not based on solid evidence and is unfounded. The company places a high priority on 

water resource protection and employs advanced wastewater treatment and water 

recycling processes and technologies, achieving zero external discharge of wastewater. 

To ensure that the water quality around the mine is not affected by the company's 

production activities, the company has installed modern water quality monitoring 

stations upstream and downstream of the Mogiyon River flowing through the mining 

area, with water quality at all 52 monitoring points meeting standards. The company 

regularly invites environmental organizations, trade unions, and community 

representatives to attend public disclosure meetings of environmental test results and 

discloses data tested by the national central laboratory to the environmental protection 

agency and the community to ensure transparency in environmental information. In 

addition, the analysis and monitoring center under the government's environmental 

protection committee has conducted multiple monitoring of the water, soil, and air 

environment around the company, with the results meeting relevant standards. 

3.Regarding Public Health 

The company has obtained health-related certificates issued by the Panjakent City 

Health and Epidemic Prevention Station and Hospital, showing that gold mining has not 

affected health issues. The average birth rate in Panjakent City and rural areas is 23.5‰, 

while the average birth rate in the Kosatarosh Township community is 24‰, with no 

significant difference in birth rates between rural areas around the company and the 

city area, and even some rural areas have higher birth rates than the city average. 

According to the 2021 statistical medical report, the cancer incidence rate in the 

Kosatarosh Township community is the same as in other township communities in 

Panjakent City. 

3.Regarding the Allegations of Operating without Licenses and Being Fined for 

 Environmental Damage: After verifying with relevant departments, there have been no 

such allegations, and the accusation is unfounded. 

Zeravshan operates the mine with high environmental standards, promoting local 

economic and social development with the concept of "common development," and 

welcomes supervision from all stakeholders of the company. 

ESG Office 

Zijin Mining Group Co., LTD. 

 
 
 
 尊敬的商业和人权资源中心： 

我们收到您的来函，同时也关注到了这篇文章，现对文章中的指控进行如下澄

清： 

1.  关于社区关系 

（1）关于土地许可 

泽拉夫尚征地、用地过程严格遵守法律法规，包括制定规划、提交申请、村民协

商、获得政府三级审批、办理土地权证等，均获得相应批准并留有文件。我们公司在

架和协商基础上向土地原使用者支付了农业损失和开发补偿金。同时我们建立了完善

的社区沟通与申诉机制，村民如在取得土地许可的过程中出现争议，可通过申诉机制

（2）关于社区投入承诺 

公司按计划持续履行发展洪格隆村的义务，已完成的社区投资项目包括修复洪格

隆村-乔理保格公路 4 公里，修建供水管道价值为 104 万索莫尼，修复村里第 83 号学

校价值超过 5.5 万索莫尼，并支付 270 万索莫尼的担保金。 

公司致力于与所有周边社区建立良好关系，使周边社区共享矿山发展成果。在社

区传统农业和特色种植产业发展、基础设施建设、弱势群体帮扶、教育卫生文化体育

设施建设等方面都有不同程度的投入，公司对社区的投入超过 1328 万美元。 

2.  关于环保 

（1）  关于周边农作物受影响问题 

全球变暖和咸海干涸对中亚生态造成广泛影响，这是广为人知的事实。近年来，

西风携带的黑色沙尘也对泽拉夫尚山谷地区造成了影响，导致树木和农作物表面附着

黑灰，影响农作物和水果生长。公司在了解到这一情况后，组织了相关培训，帮助农

民应对这些自然现象，部分掌握了知识并采取了应对措施的农民成功避免了黑灰的影

响。未来公司还将继续对社区农民提供培训，帮助他们更好地应对气候变化带来的挑

战。 

（2）  关于水质问题 

关于文中提到的大量鱼类死亡及被罚款的指控，没有扎实的事实依据，为不实指

控。公司高度重视水资源保护，采用先进的废水处理和水循环工艺和技术，实现了废

水对外零排放。为确保矿山周边水质不受公司生产活动影响，公司在流经矿区的马吉

 
 安河上下游均安装有现代化水质监测站，52 个监测点水质均达标。公司定期邀请环保

组织、工会、社区代表参加环境检测结果公示会，并向环保局和社区披露国家中心实

验室检测的数据，确保环境信息公开透明。另外，政府环保委员会下属的分析监控中

心多次对公司周围的水、土壤和空气环境状况进行监测，结果均符合相关标准。 

3.  关于公共健康 

公司取得了彭吉肯特市卫生防疫站及医院开具的与健康相关证明，数据显示金矿

开采并未影响健康问题。彭吉肯特市和乡村的平均出生率为 23.5‰，科萨塔罗舍乡的

平均出生率为 24‰，公司周边乡村出生率与市区平均出生率并无明显差别，甚至个别

乡村出生率高于市区平均出生率。根据 2021 年统计医疗报告的数据，科萨塔罗舍乡的

癌症发病率与彭吉肯特市其他乡相同。 

4.  关于未取得证照及对环境造成损害进行罚款：经与相关机构核实查证，未发

生过指控相关事宜，该指控不实。 

泽拉夫尚以高环保标准运营矿山，以“共同发展”理念促进当地经济和社会发展，同

时也接受和欢迎社会各界监督。 

ESG 办公室 

紫金矿业集团股份有限公司

(By Email) 

Business & Human Rights Resource Centre 
London, UK 

Attn: Isobel Archer- Labour & Migrant Worker Rights 

Dear BHRRC, 

UN Working Group for Arbitrary Detention – Opinion No. 12/2024 concerning Abdullah Ibhais 

Thank you for your email of 30th July 2024 seeking our feedback on the abovementioned UN 
Working Group advisory opinion.  

Mr. Ibhais first reached out to adidas, along with other FIFA Sponsors, in September 2021.  

At the time, we explained that we held no relationship with his employer, i.e. the Supreme 
Committee, and it was mutually agreed that he should raise his complaint directly with FIFA 
using their World Cup 2022 grievance mechanism, which he did.    

FIFA followed up and engaged with Supreme Committee and the Qatari government, as the 
legal proceedings continued. 

Mr. Ibhais’ family kept us abreast of his legal case, which went through several rounds of 
appeal until reaching the Court of Cassation, Qatar’s apex appellant body. On appeal, Mr. Ibhais 
received a reduced prison sentence, but the court did not overturn his conviction. 

His family also kindly shared with us the recent opinion of UN Working Group on Arbitrary 
Detention, which has challenged the legality of this conviction and requested that the Qatari 
government immediately remedy the situation.  

On our part we have raise this case with FIFA, to understand what steps they can take and how 
best we can support their follow-up actions. 

Sincerely,  

William Anderson  
Vice President, Global  
Social & Environmental Affairs

response_text:
Response to BHRRC further to articles released in media re demonstrations in Kampala in 
August 2024 (August 9th and August 26th). 

Reference is made to an invitation from Business Human Rights Resource Center to TotalEnergies to 
respond to media reports alleging violation of freedom of expression and arrests of citizens protesting 
against the operations of the East Africa Crude Oil Pipeline. 

The Companies, TotalEnergies EP Uganda and EACOP are both committed to the respect of human 
rights, including the right to freedom of expression and assembly as stated in their respective Human 
Rights Policy which can be accessed here and here. To ensure that the Government Security Forces 
equally respect these rights, the Companies have maintained regular engagement with them. The 
relationship is managed by Companies’ Security/ NGO & Human Rights teams which continuously 
engage  with  Police  by  raising  their  awareness  of  the  national  and  international  human  rights 
standards of law enforcement and the human rights implications of arrests during protests. 

The Companies take a proactive approach to ensuring that the project is implemented in accordance 
with internationally recognized human rights standards and the Voluntary Principles on Security and 
Human Rights (VPSHR). The Companies communicate with relevant government officials on Human 
Rights  and  advocate  for  professional  conduct  of  police  and  army  units.  In  particular,  they  have 
organized trainings of law enforcement officers and security officers on VPSHR and internationally 
recognized human rights. In 2024 alone, 85 Government Security personnel from Uganda Oil and Gas 
Police,  Tourism  Police  and  Uganda  Wildlife  Authority  Rangers,  have  participated  as  well  as  794 
Private  Security  Guards  working  on  the  project  sites.  The  trainings  cover  themes  related  to  the 
protection of human rights, particularly those of HRDs.  

As soon as the Companies are informed of ongoing demonstrations, they usually mobilize personnel 
to the site of the protest to seek to engage with protestors and understand their concerns and receive 
their petition if any. 

In addition, whenever TEPU is alerted of allegations of threats, intimidation, harassment, or violence 
against Human Rights Defenders in relation to its activities or EACOP Ltd.’s activities in Uganda, the 
Country Security Team will typically visit the police station and request information on the protestors’ 
welfare,  and  advocate  for  the  need  to  respect  the  human  rights  of  the  HRDs.  Where  particular 
concerns are raised in this regard, TEPU may escalate its engagement for instance by contacting the 
Commander of the Uganda Oil and Gas Police, or the Ministry of the Internal Affairs.   

For  example,  during  the  recent  protests  of  9th  and  26th  August  2024,  TEPU’s  security  department 
closely monitored the two cases of arrests and detention. In both instances, we  engaged with the 
police to ensure that the demonstrators' rights and well-being were respected throughout the legal 
proceedings.  All  47  arrested  protestors  of  August  9th  2024  were  released  the  same  day  after 
identifying themselves, while the 20 protestors from 26th August 2024 demonstration were charged 
in court. They were granted bail on 6th September 2024.  

On  both  occasions,  TEPU  engaged  closely  with  the  local  police,  attending  court  hearings  and 
maintaining regular contact with the Oil and Gas Police commander to ensure the demonstrators' 
rights are respected.  

 TEPU  and  EACOP  reiterate  that  open  dialogue  with  civil  society  is  essential  and  welcome  the 
opportunity to engage in constructive dialogue as we work together to obtain long lasting peaceful 
solutions.

response_text:
November 4, 2024 

Rio Tinto response to Business & Human Rights Resource Centre 

Rio Tinto’s focus remains on constructive engagement and meaningful action with local 
stakeholders through the Panguna Mine Legacy Impact Assessment. Rio Tinto 
recognises the importance of understanding and addressing the environmental, and 
directly connected social and human rights impacts that have occurred since mining 
operations ceased abruptly in 1989 due to civil war. 

Rio Tinto's Ongoing Commitments 

• 

• 

Independent Legacy Impact Assessment: Since 2022, Rio Tinto has been 
actively participating in an independent assessment of the Panguna Mine's 
legacy impacts. This comprehensive evaluation is being undertaken by an 
independent engineering consultant and is overseen by a diverse committee 
including representatives from local communities, BCL, the Autonomous 
Bougainville Government (ABG), the Independent State of Papua New Guinea, 
and the Human Rights Law Centre. Rio Tinto awaits the final report later this year 
and is committed to engaging with all parties on the next steps.  
Infrastructure Safety: In August 2024, Rio Tinto, ABG and BCL signed a 
Memorandum of Understanding to address concerns around future risks of 
ageing infrastructure as identified by the independent engineering consultant. 
The primary objectives are to mitigate potential hazards and enhance community 
safety. To achieve these goals, the parties have scheduled work on these 
structures to begin in the fourth quarter of 2024. 

•  Water and Sanitation: In conjunction with the Legacy Impact Assessment and 
efforts to address ageing infrastructure, Rio Tinto is supporting a water and 
sanitation project in Central Bougainville, in cooperation with the ABG. 

•  Collective remedy: Rio Tinto is seeking to partner with key stakeholders, such as 
the ABG and BCL, to design and implement a remedy framework to respond to 
the impacts identified through the Independent Legacy Impact Assessment. This 
will include targeted engagement with impacted stakeholders, such as 
representatives from communities in the river tailings area, to ensure community 
concerns are incorporated into the remedy framework. 

For more information, visit https://www.riotinto.com/en/news/trending-topics/panguna-
mine

response_text:
December 5, 2024 

[By Email] 

Business & Human Rights Resource Centre 
London, UK 

Dear BHRRC,  

Response to allegations on working conditions at Jerash Holdings (Jordan) 

Thank you for reaching out to adidas for a response to the Arbetaren news article ‘Behind the Seams: Life in 
Jordan’s hidden textile industry’, which refers to poor working conditions at Jerash Holdings. 

We can confirm that Jerash Holdings is a supplier to one of our apparel licensees and as such it has been the 
subject of regular social compliance audits, with the most recent audit having been completed in October 
2024. The facility is also enrolled into the ILO’s Better Work Jordan program and is regularly visited by the ILO 
team, with their most recent audit having been conducted in July 2024.  

Based on information shared by our licensee, we understand that working hours in excess of 60 hours per 
week were previously raised as a non-compliance, which the facility attributed to delays in receiving materials 
inputs during the Red Sea shipping disruptions in 2024.  

The issue of high production targets is a common challenge for the textile industry in Jordan, and our licensee 
is working closely with the factory to implement corrective actions, including optimizing production planning 
and reallocating resources.  

To further strengthen channels by which workers can raise grievances and complaints, our licensee monitors 
the operational effectiveness of established channels, including Welfare Officers, an Open Door Policy, PICC 
Committees, hotline numbers, and suggestion boxes. Additionally, our licensee is working with the factory to 
implement a mobile application for a workers grievance platform to further enhance worker confidence in 
reporting issues.  

The other allegations raised in the article were not validated or corroborated by the licensee’s earlier audits 
or by Better Work Jordan’s July 2024 audit, and these warrant further investigation. Our licensee is following-
up with the factory. 

We will continue to engage with our licensee in investigating and addressing any confirmed workplace 
violations at Jerash Holdings and to support remediation where necessary. 

Please do not hesitate to contact us with any further questions or clarification. 

Kind regards, 

William Anderson 
Vice President, Global  
Social & Environmental Affairs

Title: Zijin Mining's response to journalist investigation highlights negative impact of industrial and artisanal cobalt mining on women's reproductive health
Responded To: DRC: Reports reveal negative environmental and health impacts of industrial and artisanal cobalt mining; incl. co. Response
Tags: Chinese Overseas Investment|Clean, Healthy & Sustainable Environment|Occupational Health & Safety|Personal Health|Women
story_text: DRC: Reports reveal negative environmental and health impacts of industrial and artisanal cobalt mining; incl. co. response - Business & Human Rights Resource Centre
response_text:
Dear Business & Human Rights Resource Centre, 

Thank  you  for  your  correspondence  and  attention.  We  greatly  appreciate  and  commend  your 
impartial  and  objective  approach  in  considering  and  publishing  the  company's  statements  and 
clarifications on this matter.   

First  and  foremost,  we  express  deep  concern  regarding  the  health  issues  mentioned  in  the 
Mongabay report involving artisanal miners and extend our sympathy for their situation. However, 
we would like to clarify that, as of the publication of Mongabay's report, COMMUS has not received 
any  complaints  concerning  such  health  issues  allegedly  caused  by  mining  activities,  whether 
through  government  or  community  channels,  or  via 
its  community  office,  community 
representatives, phone lines, or email. Nor did Mongabay seek inquiries or file complaints with us. 
This does not match Mongabay's assertion that Zijin Mining Group and COMMUS were contacted. 

After  a  thorough  review  of  the  report,  we  believe  that  Mongabay  may  have  confused  the 
distinctions  and  relationships  between  Artisanal  and  Small-scale  Mining  (ASM)  and  Large-scale 
Mining (LSM). For reference, the International Council on Mining and Metals (ICMM) provides the 
following challenges regarding ASM: "The ASM sector often lacks basic worker health and safety 
provisions  and  workplace  dangers  include  a  lack  of  training,  poor  ventilation,  lack  of  safety 
equipment,  improper  use  of  chemicals,  and  outdated  equipment.  Women  and  children  are 
frequently  involved."  (https://www.icmm.com/en-gb/our-work/social-performance/indigenous-
peoples-and-human-rights/collaborate-artisanal-mining) As an LSM operation, COMMUS adheres 
to strict standards and protocols concerning safety, health, and environmental protection. Based 
on these clarifications, we would like to make the following statements: 

1. 

The individuals interviewed in the report are local female miner engaged in ASM. Statements 
made  by  Suzanne  Ngwewe  and  Kulemba  Samba  also  confirm  that  these  women  lack  the 
necessary  personal  protective  equipment,  and  that  unregulated,  unprotected  artisanal 
mining poses serious negative impacts on their safety, health, and the natural environment. 
According to data from institutions like the World Bank, approximately 10 million people in 
the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) directly or indirectly depend on the ASM sector, and 
ASM accounts for about 20% of the mining production in the DRC. To address these issues, 
the DRC has established SAEMAPE (Service for Assistance and Management of Artisanal and 
Small-scale Mining) to oversee and regulate ASM activities, with professional ASM groups and 
organizations also established locally. The societal challenges faced by the ASM sector require 
joint attention and support from all stakeholders worldwide. As stated in the report, these 
artisanal miners have entered the COMMUS waste dump area illegally. Out of consideration 
for their livelihoods, COMMUS does not enforce evictions but has attempted to guide them 
away in an orderly manner. However, it should be noted that these miners mainly collect hard 
rocks from the dump site for use as building materials, rather than extracting ore. 

2.  As a responsible LSM, COMMUS places a high priority on the management of environmental 
protection, occupational health and safety, and strives to minimize any impact on surrounding 
communities,  residents,  and  employees  (including  contractors).  For  instance,  COMMUS 

 
 
 
 
 
 provides  occupational  health  and  safety  training  for  employees,  equips  them  with 
comprehensive  protective equipment,  and  undertakes extensive  greening  and landscaping 
efforts in the factory area and waste dump slopes. Additionally, COMMUS has constructed 
retaining walls and dust suppression systems along the ore transport route and around the 
plant  boundaries.  In  collaboration  with  relevant  government  regulatory  bodies,  COMMUS 
also  regularly  conducts  water  and  air  quality  monitoring  to  ensure  compliance  with 
environmental  standards.  Under  such  rigorous  management,  COMMUS  has  maintained 
favorable occupational health and safety performance levels and has been actively engaging 
with stakeholders to improve its performance. 

3. 

To  enhance  COMMUS's  grievance  mechanism  and  ensure  that  health  and  safety  concerns 
from  local  residents  are  not  overlooked,  our  field  team  visited  other  hospitals  in  the 
community  where  the  report's  referenced  hospital  is  located.  However,  the  results 
contradicted the claims made in the Mongabay report. After reviewing the past three years' 
medical  data  from  EMERGENCE,  BORA,  and  PRODIGE  DE  L'ETERNEL  hospitals  in  the  same 
community,  we  found  no  evidence  of  the  purported  disease  surge.  Moreover,  COMMUS 
visited  Polyclinique  Manass é ,  which  provides  medical  care  to  our  employees  and  their 
families, and also found no evidence of such issues. 

4.  Over the years, in line with our commitment to "Mining for a Better Society," COMMUS has 
been actively listening to community opinions and needs to help improve the quality of life 
for residents. However, it is undeniable that with the rapid expansion of Kolwezi city, there 
has  been  a  constant  influx  of  migrants,  which  has  brought  new  social  challenges  to 
communities  like  the  one  where  the  Trinité  Medical  Center  is  located.  COMMUS  remains 
committed  to  fulfilling  its  social  responsibilities  by  community  investments  and  welfare  in 
areas such as water supply, education, and healthcare to alleviate these new social issues and 
help improve residents' quality of life. 

In  conclusion,  we  would  like  to  reiterate  that,  as  a  responsible  mining  company,  COMMUS  will 
continue to strictly comply with relevant laws, regulations, and industry standards in the DRC, and 
carry out robust and responsible management of environmental protection, occupational health 
and safety. We are also committed to subjecting ourselves to oversight from various government 
authorities, social institutions, and local communities. 

Thank you again for your email and attention. 

Yours sincerely, 

GAO Juntao 
Assistant to ESG Officer 
Zijin Mining Group Co., Ltd.

Greeting Business & Human Rights Resource Centre, 

Thank you for your email. 

In  response  to  the  report  released  by  China  Labor  Watch,  we  unequivocally  reject  the 
accusations  against  Zijin.  These  allegations  are  founded  on  preconceived  assumptions, 
ignoring positive evidence, and leading to misleading conclusions. 

Importantly, Serbia ZiJin Copper doo Bor (SZC) fully adheres to the  SA8000 standard, the 
world's 
leading  social  certification  program.  This  compliance  encompasses 
requirements  of  the  International  Labor  Organization  (ILO)  and  its  conventions, 
including  those  concerning  forced  or  compulsory  labor,  working  hours,  freedom  of 
movement, earnings, accommodation, healthcare, nutrition, legal rights, and more. Its 
compliance  has  been  validated  through  third-party  certification,  demonstrating  that  its  work

applicable  procedures  and  instructions  are  distributed  across  all  locations  and 
factories, ensuring its employees are well-aware of their rights and obligations. 

Moreover, adherence to the SA8000 standard is a mandate not only for SZC but also for its 
contractors and suppliers, ensuring consistent implementation of these standards in ongoing 
operations. 

SZC  fosters  transparent  communication,  including  anonymous  channels  for  reviewing 
documentation and submitting complaints or objections to management. Its website offers an 
email  address  for  anonymous  correspondence,  and  employees  are  made  aware  they  can 
contact the certification body directly. Secure mailboxes, unmonitored by cameras, are also

Dear Business & Human Rights Resource Centre, 

Thank you for your email. 

We  express  regret  that  China  Labor  Watch  has  merely  reiterated  its  previous  misleading 

conclusions in response to our proactive reply, which we continue to firmly oppose. 

We view our employees as essential partners in value creation, and we are committed to protecting 

labor rights. Our company  in Serbia fully  complies with applicable labor laws  and international 

standards,  including  the  UN  Guiding  Principles  on  Business  and  Human  Rights  and  the  ILO 

Declaration  on  Fundamental  Principles  and  Rights  at  Work.  We  ensure  the  legitimate  rights  of 

workers, including personal freedom, lawful working hours, competitive wages, good healthcare 

and accommodation standards, and we firmly oppose any form of forced labor and infringement 

of employee rights. To enhance transparency and accountability, we provide multiple channels for 

all workers and stakeholders to anonymously lodge complaints, offering credible evidence to help 

us identify risks and make improvements, such as dedicated email addresses and secure mailboxes. 

We also require our suppliers and contractors to meet the same high standards. 

Over  the  past  two  years,  we  have  been  working  to  enhance  our  human  rights  protection 

mechanisms and levels through collaboration with various stakeholders, including independent 

third-party audits we mentioned last time, and engaging in dialogues and cooperation with unions, 

as well as conducting employee satisfaction surveys. These efforts are part of our commitment, 

and we are considering future collaborations with more stakeholders in Serbia to conduct human 

rights due diligence to continuously improve labor rights. We recognize that the work to improve 

labor rights is an ongoing endeavor, and we are dedicated to making sustained progress in this 

area. 

We appreciate the attention from all external stakeholders and hope that when they have concerns, 

they  will  communicate  directly  with  us  to  verify,  helping  us  continuously  enhance  our  social 

performance.  While  achieving  perfection  in  protecting  labor  rights  presents  its  challenges,  we 

remain fully committed to enhancing our efforts and working with all stakeholders to make our 

company in Serbia a trusted family for our employees. 

Lastly,  we  would  like  to  underscore  once  again  that  through  investment  and  technological 

innovation, we have revitalized the century-old Bor Copper Mine in Serbia, which was on the brink 

of bankruptcy, creating 13,000 jobs. The average employee salary has increased by over 100% in 

the  past  six  years,  exceeding  the  national  average  wage  by  49%.  Our  efforts  are  driving  the 

sustainable  development  of  Serbia's  mining  industry,  benefiting  every  individual  and  family 

associated with us, which is key to achieving shared prosperity in the context of globalization. 

Sincerely, 

ESG Office 

Zijin Mining Group Co., Ltd.

To the attention of FIDH 

Kampala Dec 6th 2024 

With  reference  to  the  draft  report,  you  sent  us  on  November  12th,  we  would  like  to  provide  the 
following general comments regarding the Tilenga project. 

Although  we  appreciate  the  opportunity  to  provide  you  with  comments,  we  would  like  to  firmly 
express  our  dismay  at  reading  the  document  for  two  major  reasons.  Firstly,  its  content  does  not 
reflect  in  any  way  the  quality  of  policies,  mechanisms  and  actions  taken  on  the  ground  and  the 
progress made by TotalEnergies EP Uganda (TEPU) in the field of Human Rights. Furthermore, the 
draft report reflects neither our transparency practices nor our discussions over the last four years.  

The way in which the report is presented is questionable and is not at all balanced or representative 
of  the  reality  on  the  ground.  Feedback  from  local  communities  indicate  that  TEPU’s  actions  to 
address  project’s  impacts,  to  remedy  these  and  to  bring  benefits  are  appreciated.  Although  we 
recognize there is still room for improvement, TEPU rejects the false statement contained in the draft 
report.  

Over the past four years, we have maintained continuous dialogue and shared numerous documents 
and information with your organization. Additionally, we have made information about the Tilenga 
Project publicly available. This should have enabled you to document the report more thoroughly 
and recognize the quality and progress of our Company’s social performance.  

We  are  surprised  to  find  that  your  draft  report  primarily  highlights  some  malfunctions  without 
acknowledging the policies, mechanisms and actions we have implemented. This raises concerns 
about  the  validity  of  your  survey  methodology  and  the  representativeness  of  the  individuals 
interviewed. 

Additionally,  we  disagree  with  the  document’s  portrayal  of  TotalEnergies’  responsibilities  in  the 
mentioned projects (Tilenga, EACOP, Kingfisher). As previously stated, TEPU serves as the operating 
partner for the Tilenga project and as an investing partner, alongside the operating partner CNOOC 
Uganda  ltd  for  the  Kingfisher  project.  TotalEnergies  is  a  shareholder  in  EACOP  Ltd,  which  is 
responsible for the EACOP project.  

As we have discussed in various occasions, whether we act as an operating partner or an investing 
partner, we conduct our projects and we encourage our partners to conduct projects in accordance 
with highest international standards, including  the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business 
and Human Rights (UNGPs).

As mentioned previously, TEPU has in place the Fundamental Principles of Purchasing (FPP) that guides 
contracts with contractors. Contract provisions include requirements to incorporate the principles in the 
FPPs in sub-contracts.  
TEPU  offers  trainings  to  convey  our  company’s  human  rights  commitments  and  outline  the  specific

In addition to the above, the company requires all contractors to establish internal grievance mechanisms 
to provide channels of redress for disputes that arise in the employment relationship, and to develop good 
workplace practices aimed at preventing labour rights infringements. 

In 2023, the “Worker’s Voice Tool” for monitoring contractors’ workers’ grievances and complaints 
was rolled out at 2 contractor sites. Surveys are launched every 3 months. This initiative has allowed 
the  Project  to  collect  continuous  feedback  on  working  conditions  on  site  directly  from  workers 
through surveys sent to their mobile phones, understand any emerging issues that arose during the 
3-month period covered by that survey and make fast corrective actions before they escalate. With 
each  survey,  TEPU has been  able  to  exercise its leverage  to remind the contractors to develop an 
action plan to address issues identified.

HUMAN RIGHTS REPORT 2023 AMENDED3 (page 9)

environment  &  social  management  processes  and  capabilities  are  evaluated  as  part  of  the 
contractor selection process to ensure that they can meet the defined minimum requirements of the 
project (see document below page 25). 

ESMP-ONLINE-COPY-APPROVED-.pdf 

Floodings close to CPF 

In  May  2022  and  again  in  March  2023  and  early  2024,  Buliisa  district  experienced  heavy  downpours 
resulting in the occurrence of flash floods in some areas close to the Central Processing Facility (CPF) and 
in some instances, impacting neighbouring land.    

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 Measures have been put in place to address the flooding around the project facilities that are in 
flood prone areas, including the construction of retention ponds at the industrial area. The ponds 
are designed to retain surface rainwater runoff within Industrial Area so that the outflow is gradual and 
controlled  and  the  consequences  arising  from  excessive  runoff  downstream of the  Industrial  Area  are 
mitigated. Retention ponds have also been established at all well pads in the south, additional land was 
purchased outside the industrial area for water management. Studies to determine additional measures 
to manage surface water runoff are ongoing.  

PAPs who were affected by excess storm runoff were compensated for crop losses following assessment 
and verification exercise. For example, farmers whose gardens were impacted in 2022 have since been 
compensated by TEPU following approval of the loss assessment report by the Chief Government Valuer 
in the Ministry of Lands Housing and Urban Development. For the farmers whose gardens were affected 
in 2023 and early 2024, assessments were carried out and compensation was effected for the affected 
people. Additionally, land has been purchased outside the industrial area to manage surface water and 
prevent flooding in future. 

Human Wildlife conflicts 

As  previously  mentioned  in  our  correspondence,  TEP  Uganda  has  been  working  with  Wildlife 
Conservation  Society  (WCS)  and  the  Uganda  Wildlife  Authority  (UWA)  in  monitoring  the  ranging 
behaviour  of  elephants  in  and  around  Murchison  Falls  National  Park.  The  program  involves  GPS 
collaring of female and male elephants to understand their individual movement patterns, and this 
has  been  ongoing  since  2013.  The  data  so  far  shows  that  the  core  ranges  of  collared  individuals 
outside  the  park boundary  have  not  changed  since  commencement  of  oil and  gas activities, and 
contrary to the claims, it is reasonable to assume that it is not directly linked to the activities ongoing 
inside the park.  

-  For more information, please refer to below TEPU biodiversity report (page 38). 

totalenergies_ep_uganda_biodiversity_report_2024.pdf 

Avoiding and Reducing impacts such as visual and noise disturbances are of utmost importance and 
have been a major focus for our project teams since the initial design studies in 2015. Please see 
above mentioned TEPU biodiversity report (page 27).

From: Pam Bell, Senior Manager Sustainable Development at Glencore  

To: Caroline Avan, Head of Natural Resources and Just Energy Transition Team at the 
Business & Human Rights Resource Centre 

Dear Caroline, 

Thank you for reaching out to Glencore on the topics detailed below. 

•  KCC contractor salaries: 

in April 2023 we provided a response to the NGOs RAID and CAJJ on this topic, which was 
included in their report. It should be noted RAID and CAJJ’s report was for a number of 
cobalt producers in the DRC, not specifically KCC. In terms of the work we have 
undertaken, we developed a living wage methodology to evaluate the status of our 
employee salaries (including benefits) against local living wage data. We worked with 
Business for Social Responsibility (BSR) on the provision of local living wage information as 
a comparison of the payroll and benefits data relating to our employees. We continually 
review salaries and discuss them with union representatives as part of collective 
bargaining agreements to ensure that our wages are competitive in the market.  

Glencore’s Supplier Code of Conduct requires companies supplying contractors to comply 
with all applicable laws, including those concerning labour rights. Our Supplier Code of 
Conduct also sets an expectation that our suppliers respect the ILO Core Labour 
Standards, treat their workers fairly and with respect and respects the rights to lawful 
freedom of association and collective bargaining. We expect our suppliers to offer fair and 
transparent terms and conditions of employment including fair remuneration, working 
hours, and working conditions. In addition, the DRC Provincial Labour Inspector conducts 
an annual inspection to ensure all employees, including those employed as contractors, 
receive the minimum wage, and comply with DRC labour law.  KCC’s supplier agreements 
are required to contain standard terms and conditions on the requirement for robust health 
and safety management programmes, upholding respect for human rights, the prevention 
of child labour, good working conditions and fair salaries. 

Since 2020, KCC has successfully participated in the Responsible Minerals Initiative’s 
programme for its Responsible Minerals Assurance Process. Supplier due diligence was a 
core part of this third-party assessment. The report on this assessment is available on our 
website. 

 
 
 •  Volcan environmental pollution:  

Note Glencore divested its controlling interest in Volcan in May 2024 and the following 
details are only applicable to prior to the date of divestment. More than a hundred years of 
mining in the Pasco region have resulted in numerous challenges. Since 2018 and until 
divestment, Glencore supported Volcan's management team to develop and implement a 
social and environmental management plan to help mitigate the environmental impact of 
Cerro de Pasco. From the end of 2020 to mid-2021, Glencore appointed an external 
consultant, ERM, to carry out environmental health and safety and social due diligence of 
Cerro de Pasco's operations. 

While part of the Glencore Group, Volcan was committed to working in partnership with 
regional authorities, national government agencies and representatives of local 
communities to address concerns. Volcan established strategic partnerships to identify, 
monitor address the health impacts of heavy metal exposure in local communities and 
conducted health campaigns, community workshops and awareness sessions on topics 
such as personal care and hygiene, healthy eating, and anaemia prevention. It also 
provided the local community with access to health services, including general medicine, 
paediatrics, gynaecology, ultrasound, physiotherapy, and nutrition. Volcan worked in 
partnership with the Ministry of Health (MINSA) to provide financial support and develop 
action plans for children with high blood lead levels, as well as funding a study to 
investigate blood lead levels in populations in the Huayllay and Huaychao communities. 

Studies were established to understand the possible sources and pathways of lead and 
other heavy metals. Volcan strengthened its understanding of potential air, soil, and water 
impacts at the processing plant in Cerro de Pasco through reviewing the monitoring 
network and increasing monitoring frequency, as well as changing practices to reduce lead 
dust within the operation and on surrounding roads. Studies were analysing closure 
options, including socio-economic and environmental assessments. Monitoring data from 
the 22 air quality monitoring stations operating at Cerro de Pasco showed that their 
activities had no material impact on air quality and that their emissions were within 
permissible limits. 

•  Kazzinc air pollution: 

We understand that the rally mentioned in this allegation did not specifically reference 
Kazzinc. At the time of the rally, Kazzinc did not receive any complaints relating to 
environmental issues via its hotline or on social media. Kazzinc undertakes continuous 
monitoring of its emissions using an automated monitoring system. The data generated is 

 automatically sent to relevant government agencies. Kazzinc’s approach to managing its 
emissions and its monitoring systems supports compliance with permitted limits. 

On occasions when weather conditions lead to a build-up of emissions from industrial 
facilities operating in the region, state inspectors, through a memorandum of 
understanding with Kazzinc, are granted access to sites without prior authorisation to 
undertake additional monitoring of emission sources. Kazzinc proactively engages with 
state authorities also in case of general inspections and audits on environmental 
performance. 

As always, we are happy to discuss further if required. 

Kind regards,  

Pam

Title: Response from Rio Tinto
Responded To: USA: Allegations of environmental pollution at Bingham Canyon mine
story_text: USA: Allegations of environmental pollution at Bingham Canyon mine - Business & Human Rights Resource Centre
response_text:
Response to the Business and Human Rights Resource Centre (BHRRC) outreach dated 
March 3, 2025.  

The information about the Bingham Canyon Mine reported in the Salt Lake Tribune is based on the 
mine’s reporting to EPA’s Toxic Release Inventory (TRI), which may mislead readers because 
the  articles do not explain what TRI is or how it is reported.   

The millions of tons of dirt and rock moved at the mine each year have naturally occurring trace 
levels of metals that must be reported in TRI. This movement makes us large TRI contributors. 
However, this material is simply moved from one location to another within our mine site as part of 
the excavation activity that accompanies mining. The largest contributors to our TRI reporting 
include movement of overburden material within our property and disposal of tailings which are 
stored in specifically sited, engineered, constructed and permitted facilities on site to prevent 
potential health or environmental impacts.   

We are committed to responsible mining practices and environmental stewardship and closely 
monitor operations in compliance with state, federal, and local regulations. We regularly report on 
the operational performance of our engineered, permitted facilities and check the accuracy of our 
data internally while seeking independent verification where appropriate. We voluntarily give 
detailed social and environmental performance data through our annual sustainable development 
report and climate registry. We also routinely provide environmental data to state and federal 
regulators regarding air, water, and soil quality associated with our operations. 

TRI was created by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and is an annual listing of 
types and amounts of chemical substances released into the air, water, and land by specific 
industries in the U.S. TRI reporting is generally used to help stakeholders learn about toxic 
chemicals and pollution prevention activities and supports informed decision making. Unlike TRI, 
other federal and state laws and regulations are responsible for responding to releases that have 
significant impacts on human health and the environment. The shared term ‘release’ between 
these different regulations may be particularly confusing to those not familiar with the different 
programs.  

The TRI reporting requirements apply to certain facilities that manufacture, import, process, or 
otherwise use one or more listed chemicals by the EPA. Those chemicals of greatest interest to 
the mineral processing industry are the categories of metal compounds (which include arsenic, 
cadmium, lead, copper, zinc, and other naturally occurring metals) in the material that is 
excavated.     

The dirt and rock moved at the mine have naturally occurring metals, and when we move that dirt 
and rock, we must report that movement. The millions of tons of material we move each year 
makes us a large TRI contributor. As the dirt is picked up and moved from one location to another, 
for purposes of TRI reporting, this is considered a “release” under the TRI program (not 
remediation programs implicating significant impacts to human health and the environment), even 
though the moved material stays on Kennecott property.    

The largest two contributors to Kennecott’s reporting include the movement of overburden material 
and disposal to tailings. Although this material is being safely stored in specifically sited, 
engineered, constructed, and permitted facilities, the fact that the material is moved still requires 
reporting in TRI.   

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2 / 2 

Kennecott has received publicity due to the large quantities of material it moves which require TRI 
reporting. The nature of the EPA report and the way it has been reported by the news media 
makes the “releases” appear potentially risky.  Their use of the report implicates the “release” as 
being associated with other program requirements, wrongfully suggesting significant impacts to 
human health and the environment.  As stated above, the reality is that this material is moved from 
one location to another on site and safely stored in specific facilities on site, and is regulated and 
permitted via other federal and state environmental programs.   

ENDS 
MARCH 13, 2025

response_text:
Response to Business and Human Rights Resource Centre  

07 March 2025  

Thank you for the invitation to respond to allegations of dust pollution associated with Mt Newman iron mine 
operations in Australia, specifically in relation to this news article dated 16 March 2023: 
https://www.abc.net.au/news/2023-03-17/bhp-mines-source-dust-newman-government-review/102068466 

BHP has carried out extensive work and invested significantly over the past few years in improvements to 
dust management across the Pilbara, including as part of our A$300 million Pilbara Air Quality Program. We 
know other factors like the weather and naturally occurring dust contribute to air quality in the Newman area, 
and we continue to work with the community and regulators to monitor dust levels and improve air quality 
controls. 

Health and safety will always be our number one priority for our people and to help protect the communities 
where we operate. That’s aligned with our Human Rights Policy Statement and why we have a focus on the 
management and control of dust that mining operations can generate, to avoid or mitigate potential impacts 
on air quality, health and the environment.   

In 2020, we committed further investment to enhance dust management across our supply chain in the 
Pilbara, as part of our Pilbara Air Quality program.     

Specifically in Newman, we have invested more than A$80 million in capital and A$150 million in operating 
costs over five years to identify new air quality opportunities and implement additional mitigation projects at 
our Newman mine sites. 

Capital spend on dust management improvements has included water spraying on major equipment such as 
crushers and loaded trains to reduce dust, additional dust sensors and more bitumen sealed roads. 

Iron ore products are extensively tested under a product classification system overseen by SafeWork 
Australia. These are consistently determined to be non-hazardous.    

We have provided regular updates on our air quality program to the Newman community. 

Further information about BHP’s investment in air quality can be found here. 

BHP Group Limited ABN 49 004 028 077 and its subsidiaries are members of the BHP Group.  The BHP Group is headquartered in Melbourne, Australia.

Title: Response from Zijin
Responded To: Serbia: Workers injured at Zijin's Cukaru Peki mine
Tags: Adequate Living Standards|Air pollution|Clean, Healthy & Sustainable Environment|Deaths|Fair & Equal Wages|Occupational Health & Safety|Personal Health|Protests|Soil pollution|Violation of environmental safety standards|Water pollution
story_text: Serbia: Workers injured at Zijin's Cukaru Peki mine - Business & Human Rights Resource Centre
response_text:
Dear BHRRC Team, 

Based on previous email communications, we will not respond to repeated questions and refer you to 
our prior responses. Below are our answers to the remaining questions: 

1.Concern: Waste disposal without a permit in Bor Copper Mine  

As a responsible multinational enterprise, we strictly adhere to Serbian laws and regulations and are 
deeply  committed  to  environmentally  sustainable  operations.  The  waste  management  permit  is 
directly related to the Cukaru Peki project operated by our subsidiary Serbia Zijin Mining (SZM). 

Before  the  permit  expired  in  December  2022,  SZM  submitted  a  renewal  application.  In  2023,  the 
Ministry requested supplementary data and documents (relating solely to procedural improvements, 
not  environmental  deficiencies).  SZM  promptly  complied,  resubmitting  updated  materials.  In 
September  2024,  Ministry  of  Mining  and  Energy  introduced  the  New  Guidelines  for  Submitting 
Applications for Approval of Waste Management Plan (PURO), and SZM adjusted its application to 
align with these new requirements. The permit is currently under review. 

While  Serbian  law  does  not  explicitly  define  a  "transition  period"  during  permit  applications,  EU 
waste  management  practices  generally  allow  continued  operations  pending  regulatory  decisions. 
Throughout  this  process,  SZM  has  maintained  close  communication  with  regulators  and  strictly 
adhered  to  the  updated  PURO  (aligned  with  the  latest  EU  and  Serbian  standards).  SZM  has  not 
received any directives to halt operations, and both internal and third-party independent assessments 
confirm no environmental harm has occurred. Delays in the renewal process stem from the lengthy 
regulatory  procedures  and  evolving  policies,  but  SZM  has  consistently  followed  a  compliant 
"application-amendment-reapplication" path without intentional violations. 

The  Cukaru  Peki  project  has  been  recognized  as  Serbia’s  first  green  mine.  During  the  transition 
period, environmental investments and standards were not reduced but further elevated. The project 
features  the high-standard  built  water-treatment  plant, dumps and tailings  facility  (lined with  high-
strength  impermeable  materials),  which  achieve  zero  discharge  of  industrial  wastewater  (100% 
recycling) and compliant tailings and waste disposal. 

2.Concern: Improper health and safety measures for workers of Bor Copper Mine： 

The accident that occurred on February 16, 2024, injured 10 workers and took place at the Cukaru 
Peki shaft construction project, which was contracted and independently managed by CC-3 Mining 
Construction d.o.o Bor (CC-3). CC-3 is a legally incorporated entity in Serbia with valid licenses and 
bears  direct  responsibility  for  construction  safety.  Immediately  following  the  incident,  CC-3 
activated  its  emergency  response  plan,  organized  rescue  efforts,  transported  the  injured  to  medical 
facilities,  and  issued  a  media  statement  to  publicly  disclose  information.  All  injured  workers  have 
fully recovered. Under Serbian law, the construction contractor, as an independent liability entity, is 
legally accountable for safety incidents within its operational scope. 

We deeply regret the occurrence of this incident. Zijin Mining Group and its subsidiaries prioritize 
safety  as the utmost  priority in all operations. SZM has  established a comprehensive  Occupational 
Health  and  Safety  (OHS)  management  system  covering  all  employees,  certified  under  ISO  45001, 
and implements the "4E" and "Take5" safety management mechanisms. As the project owner, SZM’s 

 
 construction contract with CC-3 explicitly mandates compliance with Serbian safety standards, and 
SZM has fulfilled its  contractual safety oversight  obligations in  full. This  includes conducting 451 
safety  inspections  and  issuing  78  rectification  notices  for  underground  construction  projects  in 
2023/2024, all of which have been fully enforced. 

3.Concern: Iron pollution as a result of Zijinshan gold and copper mine   

This  allegation  from  BHRRC  is  not  correct.  The  study  doesn’t  have  a  conclusion  that  the  high 
concentration of Fe is due to Zijinshan. 

This  research provides  a macro-level  analysis of potential effects  of Chinese mining  operations on 
water  quality.  The  research  only  illustrate  the  presence  of  mining  activities  in  western  Fujian  and 
cites  the  most  famous  mine  in  the  region,  Zijinshan,  without  establishing  any  direct  causation 
between Zijin and the reported water quality issues (namely, pH imbalance and excessive iron levels). 
There’s  no  additional  information  in  the  study  (e.g.,  detailed  data,  research  methodology)  that 
definitively links these water quality issues to Zijin's operations or proves a causal relationship.  

However, there are wide range of deposits of metals such as iron, manganese, and rare earth elements, 
as well as non-metallic minerals like kaolin and coal. It is important to highlight that water quality 
dynamics  involve  complex  interactions  among  multiple  factors.  The  study  does  not  account  for 
geological variables, including potential heavy metal leaching from naturally occurring mineralized 
rock formations inherent to the region. 

As  a  responsible  operator,  Zijin  Mining  places  ecological  stewardship  at  the  core  of  its  corporate 
philosophy.  At  Zijinshan  Gold-copper  Mine,  we  have  implemented  an  advanced  environmental 
management system integrating technological innovation and systemic restoration: 

⚫  Real-Time Monitoring Network: Established automated monitoring stations at all critical points 

for continuous water quality surveillance. 

⚫  Biomonitoring: We raise fish downstream of the mining area to serve as an early warning system 

for any leaks or pollution incidents. 

⚫  Closed-Loop  Water  Management:  Achieved  100%  wastewater  recycling  through  internal 

treatment systems. 

⚫  State-of-the-Art  Treatment  Infrastructure:  Deployed  precision  water  purification  systems  to 

ensure compliance with discharge standards. 

⚫  Ecological  Engineering:  Utilized  constructed  wetlands  for  natural  pollutant  attenuation  and 

resource recovery. 

Thank you once again for your interest and engagement.  

Sincerely, 

ESG Team 

Zijin Mining Group 

No. 1 Zijin Road, Shanghang County Longyan City, Fujian Province, PRC
