story_text: EU: Coffee sector must "cease...attacks" of deforestation legislation amid "harmful" lobbying by coffee federations, says report; incl. cos. responses & non-responses - Business & Human Rights Resource Centre
response_text:
Nestlé response to allegations regarding lobbying of the European Coffee 

Federation on the EUDR – 14 March 2025 

As the European Coffee Federation has outlined in its direct response, it has always been committed 

to the successful implementation of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) and has dedicated 

significant resources to minimize and mitigate the risk of deforestation in the coffee supply chain. It 

has never attempted to undermine the EUDR. Concerns regarding the implementation timeline of 

the EUDR were related to the absence of practical tools and guidelines needed to comply with the 

Regulation, which subsequently had an impact on the ability of all relevant actors to prepare for its 

implementation. It was not linked to the industry's willingness to comply. 

As Nestlé, we strongly support the objective of the European Commission to protect the world’s 

forests and restore forests in a sustainable way. We have consistently advocated for a mix of 

complementary measures at EU level to address global deforestation in partnership with third 

countries. Our work to achieve deforestation-free key supply chains started over a decade ago. As of 

the end of 2024, 93.5% of the total volume of our key ingredients – cocoa, coffee, meat, palm oil, pulp 

and paper, soy and sugar – are assessed as deforestation-free. Our progress has been recognized by the 

2024 Forest 500 report in which Nestlé came out as the top FMCG company.  

Thanks to our longstanding work in avoiding deforestation, we remain confident in our ability to 

comply with the EUDR. Since its entry into force, we have made significant investments to close any 

identified gaps together with our supply chain partners and we continue to work intensely in this 

area.  

We have never called for any delay of the EUDR and have always opposed any calls to re-open the 

substance of the EUDR for new negotiations. Nestlé remains supportive of the objectives of the 

EUDR and its successful implementation. We will continue to contribute to discussions on the EUDR 

implementation to support the achievement of this objective.  

For additional reference on our views and commitment to a successful implementation of the 

provisions of the EUDR, please find below several public statements clarifying that we have never 

asked for a delay or weakening of the EUDR: 

•  Reuters article on letter from Cocoa Coalition to Commission President Ursula von der Leyen 

(July 2024)  

•  LinkedIn Post from Bart Vandewaetere, Vice-President ESG Engagement Nestlé Europe “EU 

Deforestation Regulation: a delay without urgent clarifications won’t help!” (September 2024)  

•  Statement of NGOs and companies opposing calls to reopen the substance of the EUDR, and 

urging immediate release of guidance documents and FAQ (October 2024) 

 •  Cocoa Coalition Statement, opposing reopening EUDR (October 2024)  

•  Financial Times article with quote from Bart Vandewaetere, Vice-President ESG Engagement 

Nestlé Europe (November 2024) 

•  Wall Street Journal article with quote from Bart Vandewaetere, Vice-President ESG 

Engagement Nestlé Europe (November 2024)  

•  LinkedIn post from Bart Vandewaetere, Vice-President ESG Engagement Nestlé Europe “EU 
Deforestation Regulation: Adopt the 12-month delay without reopening the law!” (November 

2024)

Title: Volkswagen’s response to the report
Responded To: Tanzania: New report claims serious abuses linked to new carbon projects including one financed by Volkswagen; company responded
Tags: Access to Information|Cultural Rights|Free, prior & informed consent|Impacts on Livelihoods|Indigenous Peoples|Land Rights
story_text: Tanzania: New report claims serious abuses linked to new carbon projects including one financed by Volkswagen; company responded
response_text:
Volkswagen 
Volkswagen  ClimatePartner  takes  seriously  the  concerns  raised  in  the  report  published  by  the 
Maasai  International  Solidarity  Alliance  (MISA)  in  March  2025  regarding  soil  carbon  credit 
projects  in  Northern Tanzania.  We deeply  respect  the history, resilience,  and challenges of the 
Maasai  people.  Our  involvement  in  the  Longido  and  Monduli  Rangelands  Carbon  Project 
(LMRCP),  implemented  by  our  project  partners  Soils  for  the  Future  Tanzania  (SftFTZ,  the 
project implementing entity) and CarbonSolve LLC, is grounded in a commitment to improving 
rangeland  health,  supporting  Maasai  livelihoods,  and  promoting  climate  resilience  through 
carbon  finance.  The  project  is  designed  to  balance  traditional  pastoralist  land  use  with 
sustainable  land  management  while  ensuring  that  Maasai  communities  retain  full  control  over 
their land and benefit from participation. 
In  the  following  section,  we  would  like  to  clarify  several  key  points  in  response  to  the  claims 
made in the MISA report: 
1. Land Ownership and Rights 

  SftFTZ does not acquire or control any land within the project area. All land titles remain 
entirely under the ownership of the Maasai villages, in accordance with Tanzanian law. 
  The  project  does  not  involve  land  sales,  leases,  encumbrances  or  transfers  to  foreign 

entities. 

  Maasai  communities  will  continue  to  exercise  full  rights  over  their  land  and  maintain 

their traditional grazing practices. 

2. Contract Duration and Flexibility 

  There is a scientific consensus that soil restoration takes time. The 40-year duration of the 
project contracts is needed to support the reality that degraded grasslands, such as those 
in Northern Tanzania, can take several decades to recover. 

  This  long-term  commitment  ensures  sustainable  land  regeneration  and  stable  economic 
benefits for communities. Importantly, contracts include exit clauses, allowing villages to 
review, renegotiate, or withdraw from the agreement where they choose to do so… 

3. Free, Prior, and Informed Consent (FPIC) Process 

  Volkswagen  ClimatePartner  places  a  strong  emphasis  on  FPIC,  ensuring  that  all 
participating communities fully understand the project’s terms, benefits, and implications. 
  The FPIC process begins with an early engagement to introduce the project, explain its 
broad  concepts  and  its  progression  from  introduction  to  implementation.  This  process 
includes,  initially,  the  Memorandum  of  Understanding  (MoU)  and  results  in  the  two 
project  agreements,  namely  the  Carbon  Rights  Assignment  Agreement  and  the  Benefit 
Sharing Agreement. 

  Engagement  includes  women,  youth,  and  village  elders,  with  all  agreements  requiring 

final approval from the village assembly before implementation. 

  Dedicated  Maasai  team  members  within  SftFTZ  lead  consultations  to  ensure  cultural 

sensitivity, inclusivity, and transparency. 

  An  independent  data  management  consultancy  tracks  all  FPIC-related  activities  to 

document engagement and ensure full transparency. 

4. Pastoralist Traditions and Grazing Practices 

  The project is not designed to restrict Maasai traditions but rather to support sustainable 

pastoralism by preventing overgrazing and land degradation. 

  The  project  does  not  disrupt  traditional  grazing  but  rather  supports  it  with  financial 
benefits, ensuring its sustainability while focusing specifically on preventing overgrazing. 

   The  project  ensures  flexible  yet  secure  governance  of  grazing  activities.  While  villages 
commit  to  core  grazing  principles,  each  village  grazing  committee  designs  a  specific 
management plan that is agreed upon by participants. This plan can be adjusted over time 
to respond to changing conditions, emergencies, and community needs. 

5. Fair Benefit-Sharing Mechanism and Initial Project Payments 

  The  project  follows  the  Tanzanian  legal  framework  on  carbon  trading,  ensuring  that 

revenues are distributed fairly among stakeholders. 

  Benefit  sharing  is  guided  by  the  Tanzanian  legal  framework  as  further  negotiated 

 

between the villages and SftFTZ with oversight from the district. 
Initial project payments are used to support project preparation. The payments are made 
after  the  Benefit  Sharing  Agreements  have  been  signed  and  after  the  Rapid  Rotational 
Grazing Plans have been developed. 

6. Scientific Basis and Environmental Impact 

  There is a broad consensus among the scientific community and global institutions, such 
as  the  Intergovernmental  Panel  on  Climate  Change  (IPCC),  that  tackling  soil  and  land 
degradation—including  soil  carbon  enhancements—is  vital  for  combating  climate 
change. Carbon crediting serves as an additional tool to achieve these impacts. 

  The  project  methodology  applies  a  peer-reviewed  soil  carbon  model,  which  has  been 
approved by VERRA for use in relevant contexts, including arid and semi-arid regions of 
East Africa. 

  The methodology requires ex-post soil sampling to determine the actual accumulation of 

soil carbon over time to avoid over-crediting. 

Volkswagen  ClimatePartner  is  committed  to  ensuring  that  our  climate  initiatives  respect  land 
rights,  promote  sustainable  development,  and  create  real  benefits  for  communities.  We  are 
committed  to  ongoing  engagement  with  Maasai  communities,  independent  experts,  and 
regulatory bodies. 

For further inquiries, please contact: 
Volkswagen ClimatePartner 
communications@volkswagen-climatepartner.de

Response to enquiry from Business & Human Rights Resource Centre 

regarding Reuters’ article dated 4th of March 2025 

Respect for human rights is at the core of Nestlé’s culture and values and one of our main 

Corporate  Business  Principles.  Our  commitment  to  respecting  and  promoting  human 

rights is critical to our business strategy and a key part of our ambition to enable a just 

transition to a regenerative food system at scale. 

Our  Human  Rights  Framework  and  Roadmap  guides  our  due  diligence  approach  – 

assessing, addressing, and reporting transparently on actual and potential human rights 

risks arising directly or indirectly through our own activities or our business relationships.  

We expect all our suppliers to comply with our Nestlé Responsible Sourcing Core 

Requirements and verify supplier compliance with our requirements on a regular basis. 

We take all allegations regarding the sourcing of our ingredients very seriously. When 

we become aware of any concerns, we immediately engage with our suppliers to 

investigate. If non-compliances with our Responsible Sourcing Core Requirements are 

identified, they must be addressed through a time-bound action plan agreed with 

Nestlé, which will include prevention, mitigation and remediation actions, as 

appropriate. 

Currently, we are in contact with our gum acacia suppliers. We have requested 

assurance that the ingredients they provide to us meet our Responsible Sourcing Core 

Requirements—which includes ensuring that it is sourced in accordance with applicable 

laws and international standards on human rights.

“H&M’s response” 21 March 2025 

PT Sritex Group is no longer an active supplier to H&M Group. We 
worked with some of their factories in the past, but phased them out in 
2023 and 2024 due to changing business needs. As per our responsible 
exit routine (which follows ACT Responsible Exit Policy), we took the

and their employees. We set out a clear phase-out process during which 
we conducted a worker impact assessment and created an exit plan in 
close dialogue with the supplier. 

If you have any information about H&M products being made in their 
factories, please inform us so we can investigate.

Title: TotalEnergies response to alleged human rights violations at Mozambique LNG project
Responded To: Mozambique: CSOs call on 31 financial institutions to withdraw financial support for TotalEnergies’ Mozambique LNG project; incl. cos. responses & non-responses
story_text: Mozambique: CSOs call on 31 financial institutions to withdraw financial support for TotalEnergies’ Mozambique LNG project; incl. cos. responses & non-responses - Business & Human Rights Resource Centre
response_text:
Invitation from BHRRC to respond to allegations relating to Mozambique 

March 31st, 2025 

Response 

We have taken note of your invitation to respond to the allegations regarding the Mozambique LNG 
Area 1 project (the “Project” or “Mozambique LNG”) and are pleased to provide the below responses. 

With regard to the “alleged human rights violations linked to TotalEnergies’ operations at its - 
Afungi premises”, please note the following:  

Following recent allegations of human rights abuses by the Mozambican armed forces in 2021 during 
the  period  when  Mozambique  LNG  no  longer  had  staff  on  the  Afungi  site,  Mozambique  LNG 
conducted a review of the elements in its possession at the time of the facts which did not allow to 
identify  any  corroborating  information,  although  Mozambique  LNG  had  several  functioning 
information and grievance reporting channels at its disposal.  

In October 2024, Mozambique LNG invited the Mozambican authorities to conduct an investigation 
on these allegations. The opening of an investigation has been confirmed by the Attorney General’s 
Office of Mozambique early March 2025. 

In addition, TotalEnergies has requested the intervention of the Mozambican Commission on Human 
rights (CNDH). The CNDH confirmed on 25 March 2025 that it will carry out its own assessment of all 
relevant information to ensure that the facts are duly ascertained and that the rights of the parties 
involved  are  fully  respected.  It  has  stated  that  it  will  follow  the  investigation  launched  by  the 
Mozambican  judicial authorities  to  ensure that it is  conducted  in a transparent, fair and impartial 
manner. TotalEnergies will publish the CNDH report. 

In addition to the above information, please also find here below the links to the documents already 
made publicly available by Mozambique LNG and TotalEnergies: 

Mozambique 2024-11-26 

Investigations-performed-by-Mozambique-LNG-on-the-allegations-published-by-Politico.pdf 

Mozambique 2024-09-26 

Mozambique  LNG:  TotalEnergies  welcomes  the  launch  of  official  investigations  in  Mozambique  | 
TotalEnergies.com 

  
 
 
 
 
 
 With regard to the allegations of “communities of Afungi affected by unresolved resettlement 
violations resorted to protest at the gates of the TotalEnergies Afungi site in November; as of 17 
January, community members have expressed dissatisfaction with the compensation offered 
by TotalEnergies”, please note the following: 

(A) Resettlement context 

In addition to rights to develop the resources, the LNG project concessionaires (Area 1 and Area 4), 
have been granted rights on land use by the Government of Mozambique over an area of circa 6,000 
hectares in the Afungi peninsula covered by the DUAT (DUAT = land rights granted by the authorities 
for the onshore operations of the projects). 
A Resettlement Plan complying with national legislation and international standards was approved 
by  the  Palma  district  Government  in  2017  to  manage  the  economic  displacement  of  1,680 
households and the physical relocation of 643 households from the Quitupo village and neighboring 
production  zones  to  a  newly  built  Quitunda  village.  In  addition,  1,879  fishermen  and  intertidal 
collectors (mostly women who harvest coastal resources) were identified along with fisheries. 
The suspension of all activities (due to Force Majeure in April 2021) in Afungi came at a time when 
the Project was part way through the Resettlement Plan implementation. From the second half of 
2022, the improvement of the security context in Palma allowed for the resumption of resettlement-
related activities, socio-economic programs, and face-to-face engagements with the communities, 
despite Force Majeure still being in effect. 

(B) Compensation 

All 643 entitled households physically relocated have received their due compensation and their new 
homes in the Quitunda village, with the last group of families relocated in May 2024. 

The status of compensation payment as of 1 January 2025 is as follows: 

✓  All of the 1,680 land-based economically impacted households have been paid their entitled 

monetary compensation. 

✓  Fisheries compensation has been paid to 1,386 fishermen and intertidal collectors (mostly 

women who harvest coastal resources) and remaining ongoing. 

The  Project  continues  to  actively  work  on  the  Resettlement  process  in  order  to  reach  100%  of 
impacted  stakeholders  and  notes  that,  from  its  perspective,  the  Resettlement  process  is  well 
underway and ahead of schedule considering the two-year delay on the implementation of the RAP 
(Resettlement Action Plan) caused by the Force Majeure situation affecting the Project. 

Project’s Community Grievance Mechanism 

The  Project  maintains  a  non-judicial  Community  Grievance  Mechanism  which  follows  the 
international  standards  (IFC  grievance  management  process,  and  the  United  Nations  Guiding 
Principles for Business and Human Rights) and is readily available to households and communities 

 
 
 through  several  channels,  and  is  conducted  on  fair,  informed,  and  respectful  terms  (respect  for 
confidentiality to prevent the possible risk of reprisals). 

Since the creation of the Project’s Community Grievance Mechanism, the Project has investigated 
over 600 compensation-related grievances received and 386 were found to be legitimate. Of these, 
351 have already signed compensation agreements for which payments are being processed. 

November 2024 Demonstrations 

We would like to clarify that the November 2024 demonstrations only involved a small number of so-
called  «Newcomers”  who  participated  in  the  demonstrations.  The  members  of  the  Resettled 
community  (i.e.  those  who  have  moved  to  a  new  house  in  the  Quitunda  village)  and  of  the 
Economically affected community (i.e. those who did not have to move to a new house but who were 
compensated for the loss of an economic (farming) interest within the DUAT), did not participate in 
the demonstrations. 

Economically  affected  community  members  were  entitled  to  cash  compensation,  which  they 
received, and access to new land outside of the DUAT area, as part of the livelihood restoration plan, 
in an area reserved by the Government for this intent. The land designated for this purpose was no 
longer available as a result of the influx of vulnerable people (the “newcomers’ community”) moving 
into  those  lands.  The  Government,  the  Project  and  the  economic  community  are  looking  for 
alternative  means  to  fulfil  the  livelihood  restoration  plan  –  this  work  is  ongoing  and  remains 
constructive. 

As far as the Newcomers community members are concerned, given that they will not be asked to 
leave the land on which they have recently settled, the Project has informed this community that 
compensation  would  not  be  provided.  Upon  hearing  this,  about  50  out  of  a  total  of  2,000  of  the 
“newcomers’  community”  demonstrated  outside  of  the  gate  to  the  DUAT  area.  An  assistance 
package  to  this  group  was  agreed  at  the  end  of  2024  and  its  implementation  is  ongoing.  This 
assistance  package  include  a  one-off  payment  including  labour  cost  for  land  preparation,  the 
opportunity to participate with their land in the agricultural development program implemented by 
the Project, which includes: (i) support for food production through the provision of improved seeds 
and  technical  assistance  and  (ii)  an  income  generating  coconut  plantation,  (iii)  Government 
committing to provide security of tenure; and (iv) the implementation, in mid-term, of community 
socio-economic benefits through the formalization of community development agreements with the 
host communities and the Government. 

__________

Title: Nestlé's response to Empower, ProDESC and Coffee Watch's rejoinder
Responded To: Mexico: Pricing, purchasing practices and poverty cycles for farmers in Nestlé and Starbucks' coffee supply chain
story_text: Mexico: Pricing, purchasing practices and poverty cycles for farmers in Nestlé and Starbucks' coffee supply chain - Business & Human Rights Resource Centre
response_text:
Response to BHRRC re: Empower rejoinder – 31 March 2025 

We thank you for the opportunity to respond to the 14 March 2025 letter from Empower, ProDESC 
and Coffee Watch.  

Our  approach  to  Responsible  Sourcing  aims  to  help  build  the  foundations  to  advance 
regenerative food systems at scale. Our work is designed to contribute to the implementation in 
our supply chain of our commitment towards the UN Guiding Principles on Business and human 
rights and the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises on Responsible Business Conduct, 
thereby helping to transform production practices in a way that will impact positively on people, 
nature and climate in Nestlé’s sourcing origins.  

Our Responsibly Sourced KPI measures the performance of volumes at origin level against our 
Responsible Sourcing Core Requirements. Operationally, the criteria to define if a raw material is 
responsibly  sourced  is  that  the  material  either  can  be  traced  to  low-risk  countries  with 
subnational traceability or that the origin of the material is traceable back to the group of farms 
and  Tier  1  suppliers’  volumes  are  assessed  as  compliant  with  our  Responsible  Sourcing Core 
Requirements at production level through one of the following means: 

• 

• 

• 

Selected sustainability related certifications  

Second or third-party farm selected assessments 

On-the-ground  programs  in  which  Nestlé  directly  works  with  producers  (e.g.  Nescafé 
Plan). 

We  also  invite  you  to  peruse  our  Non-Financial  Statement  2024,  which has  been  prepared  by 
Nestlé S.A. in accordance  with Articles 964a-c of the Swiss Code of Obligations. Moreover, in 
anticipation of the Group’s future obligation to report in accordance with CSRD, the structure, 
terminology and approach of this report have been prepared with reference to the ESRS.

response_text:
30 May 2025 

Response to Business & Human Rights Resource Centre – Stellantis 

We would like to clarify that, as of today, Stellantis does not have any joint venture or formal 
collaboration with PT Vale or Huayou Cobalt.  Furthermore, there are no ongoing discussions 
between Stellantis and PT Vale nor Huayou Cobalt regarding a potential joint venture or 
partnership. 

Stellantis is dedicated to maintaining human rights and ethical principles throughout its 
supply chain, as outlined in our Code of Conduct, Human Rights Policy, and Responsible 
Purchasing Guidelines. We align with internationally recognized standards, including the 
OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises, the UN Declaration of Human Rights, and 
the UN Convention against Corruption. We take proactive measures inspired by the 
International Labour Organization (ILO) rules and the UN Guiding Principles on Business 
and Human Rights.  We require, our suppliers, contractors, and business partners to comply 
with laws, regulations, and global standards related to environmental impacts, human rights, 
labor practices, and occupational health and safety and we evaluate the human rights and 
environmental practices of Tier-1 suppliers through independent third-party audits. Finally, 
we have increased our due diligence activities to prepare with upcoming regulations such as 
the European Union Battery Regulation (EUBR) and the European Union Deforestation 
Regulation (EUDR) and have prioritized these commitments in our operations to be 
compliant with the provisions in both regulations. 

We would like to call attention to the Stellantis Integrity Helpline, a secure and confidential 
method for reporting concerns that underpins our commitment. The Integrity Helpline, which 
is reachable via the Company’s website, allows employees, contractors, suppliers, dealers and 
members of the public to report any issues that may concern vehicle safety, emissions or 
regulatory compliance, or violations to our Code of Conduct.  

Stellantis expects suppliers to offer channels for employees and stakeholders to report 
violations of law or human rights and prohibit retaliation against anyone who makes a good 
faith report of a violation of policy or law. 

Thank you again for the opportunity to respond. We would welcome the opportunity to 
further discuss our approaches if appropriate.

response_text:
29 April 2025  

(By Email) 

Business & Human Rights Resource Centre 
London, UK 

Attn: BHRRC – Labor Rights Program 

Dear BHRRC, 

Response to media article on the Adidas Arena 

Thank you for reaching out to adidas regarding a recent article about undocumented migrant 
construction workers who helped refurbish Paris’s Adidas Arena in the run up to the Olympic 
Games and remain without papers despite promises of regularization. 

adidas holds naming rights for the arena, but we hold no relationship with the municipal 
authority that owns the building, or the construction company that was commissioned to 
undertake its refurbishment for the Paris Olympics.   

As we have shared previously, adidas was not a sponsor of the Paris Olympics and we had no 
dealings with the Comité d'Organisation des Jeux Olympiques et Paralympiques de Paris 2024, 
which used the arena as part of its hosting of the summer games.  

We are of course concerned to hear that the migrant workers did not secure the residency 
permits and health insurance that had been promised to them, but this is a matter that needs to 
be taken up with the municipal government and the construction company responsible for their 
employment, in the lead up to the 2024 Olympics Games.  

If you have any additional questions, please feel free to contact us. 

Sincerely,  

William Anderson  
Vice President, Global  
Social & Environmental Affairs

response_text: TotalEnergies’ answer to BHRRC Subject: Response to the allegations in "The Obstruction Playbook" Report published by Just Share Dear Gerald and BHRRC Team, Thank you for reaching out to us regarding the allegations made in the May 2025 report titled "The Obstruction Playbook: How corporate lobbying threatens South Africa’s Just Transition," published by Just Share. As TotalEnergies, we appreciate the opportunity to address these allegations. TotalEnergies is a global integrated multi-energy company producing and supplying energy: oil and biofuels, natural gas, biogas and low-carbon hydrogen, renewables and electricity whose ambition is to get to carbon neutrality by 2050, together with society. TotalEnergies implements its integrated, balanced multi-energy strategy based on two pillars: hydrocarbons, particularly Liquified Natural Gas, and electricity, the energy at the heart of the transition. Firstly, TotalEnergies has not engaged in lobbying activities aimed at delaying and/or weakening South Africa’s carbon tax and climate legislation.   Regarding our advocacy and sector initiatives, please note that TotalEnergies supports the commitments made by governments to combat global warming as part of the Paris Agreement and publishes its positions on its corporate website1.   TotalEnergies is an active participant in both national and international business and industry associations. Since 2019, TotalEnergies has been publishing its six principles on its responsible commitment to climate change within industry associations (see p.40 of TotalEnergies’ Sustainability & Climate 2025 Progress Report2).    TotalEnergies Marketing South Africa (Pty) Ltd is a member of the Energy Council of South Africa (ECSA). The ECSA is an industry association which supports South Africa’s commitments adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the Paris Agreement and South Africa’s climate change legislation aimed at achieving Net Zero by 2050. Furthermore, the ECSA further recognises the critical importance of a successful national energy transition in meeting the decarbonisation targets whilst maintaining energy security.   TotalEnergies’ report regarding the review of industry associations was published in 2024 and can be found on its corporate website3. Every two years, TotalEnergies’ entities record memberships in industry associations. 1107 industry associations (including the ECSA) and chambers of commerce have been covered for 2023 and for which the list is available on its corporate website4.  Regarding the specific allegations in the report of Just Share, we invite you to contact the ECSA, which is better positioned to provide detailed information concerning its activities.  In addition, please note that TotalEnergies, through its subsidiaries, has been operating in South Africa since 19545 and for more than fifty years we have been committed to the energy  1 Advocacy Efforts Carried Out by TotalEnergies | TotalEnergies.com 2 totalenergies_sustainability-climate-2025-progress-report_2025_en.pdf 3 Review of industry associations 2023 4 Review 2023 professional associations and chambers of commerce Highlights 5  TotalEnergies in South Africa | TotalEnergies.com Docusign Envelope ID: 9EA1D476-0728-4933-B593-A3D5C4D4A5FB development of South Africa. Today, TotalEnergies, through its subsidiaries, is actively contributing to the country's energy transition by investing in renewable energy projects and supporting the country's move away from coal. In a region where access to energy, particularly in meeting the increasing demand for electricity, is a critical issue, TotalEnergies remains committed to addressing these challenges. In South Africa, in accordance with its balanced multi-energy strategy, TotalEnergies through its subsidiaries, maintains a network of over 560 retail sites, distributes Liquified Petroleum Gas nationwide for all domestic energy needs, undertakes exploration projects, and invests in solar and wind projects, including the Prieska solar power plant (86 MW, 27%), which has been supplying more than 70,000 homes with electricity since 2016. For more information about our multi-energy strategy in South Africa, refer to p.87 and p.105 of the TotalEnergies Universal Registration Document 2024 (URD 2024)6.  Please note that this response is not exhaustive, and TotalEnergies reserves the right to supplement its response in due course should the need arise.  Feel free to reach out if you have any further questions or require additional information.  Best regards,      Olagoke ALUKO, TotalEnergies Marketing South Africa MD/CEO  TotalEnergies Country Chair in South Africa       6 TotalEnergies Universal Registration Document 2024  Docusign Envelope ID: 9EA1D476-0728-4933-B593-A3D5C4D4A5FB

response_text: Portion 27 • Farm Waterval 306 JQ • Rustenburg • 0299 • South Africa Mailing Address: PO Box 2131 • Rustenburg • 0300 • South Africa Telephone:  +27 (0) 14 590 6000 • Telefax:  +27 (0) 14 590 6002  GLENCORE OPERATIONS SOUTH AFRICA (PTY) LTD  Registration No. 1997/017998/07 Directors:  JPM Fullard, MJ Houston, F Lambrechts, PN Mahobe, ZZD Ntlangula                                                                   Page 1  12 June 2025  Manson Gwanyanya Business & Human Rights Resource Centre The Foundry, 17 Oval Way, London, SE11 5RR Per e-mail: gwanyanya@business-humanrights.org                         kibugu@business-humanrights.org   Dear Sir,   MACUA & WAMUA report titled "Looted Promises: The Crumbs Economy of Mining and the Myth of the Just Transition//GLENCORE OPERATIONS SOUTH AFRICA (PTY) LTD (“GLENCORE”)   I trust you are well. We hereby formally respond to your emailed requests dated 28 May 2025 relating to the 2025 MACUA & WAMUA report titled "Looted Promises: The Crumbs Economy of Mining and the Myth of the Just Transition” which specifically referenced Glencore’s Waterval Mine and the mining-affected community.   1. How does your company respond to the report’s allegations that you underdelivered on the legally binding obligations in your Social Labour Plans (“SLP’s”).  We considered the content of the MACUA Report and confirms that the report contains several inaccuracies.    In relation to the Waterval Mine SLPs, over the first SLP period 2010 - 2014 period Glencore actually spent more than double the committed SLP amount and the 2nd cycle SLP from 2016-2020 was completed in full as committed to. SLP Closure reports for the above 2 SLP periods as well as final closure and Section 93 reports have been submitted to the DMPR. The 3rd SLP cycle from 2021-2025 is currently being finalized.  The legally binding obligations in our SLPs have thus been met and even exceeded.  The report falsely alleges that Glencore does not engage on matters related to SLP’s and that it is unwilling to share its SLP’s in the public domain. Our rigorous stakeholder engagements are well documented and covers community, local municipality and engagements with the Regulator. MACUA received copies of the requested SLP within a week of submitting the request. Copies of the SLP are available at the operations and is also published on the Minerals Councils website.       Page 2  2. Can you provide updated figures or independent verification on the completion and impact of your SLP projects in the area?  The DMPR as the Regulator has conducted compliance audits and has completed the closure and verification reports for the Waterval Mine SLPs for the 1st and 2nd cycle SLPs.   1st SLP:   2nd SLP:     Current 3rd SLP (still busy implementing):      Page 3    3. Has your company made its full SLP documents, budgets, and implementation reports publicly available or accessible to the affected communities? Are they available online? If yes, please provide the link.   Upon receiving a request from MACUA, Glencore shared its SLP with them on the 15th of November 2021. Glencore has made its approved SLP’s readily available on many platforms including the website of the Minerals Council of South Africa.   https://www.mineralscouncil.org.za/sa-mining/slps/slps-by-province  The regulation requiring the publication of approved SLPs (Regulation 46A of the Mineral and Petroleum Resources Development Regulations) came into effect in 2020. This regulation mandates that mining right holders must publish the approved SLP in English and one other dominant official language within the mine community within 30 days of approval. Glencore’s latest approved SLPs are publicly available at the operations, the local municipalities and on the Minerals Council website.  4. What strategies did your company use to engage the local community, particularly women and youth, in the planning and implementation of the SLP? We extensively mapped our doorstep communities. The analysis from our detailed independent community baseline studies conducted by Rasegoete & Associates, Social Surveys Community Stability Project and Synergy Global Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights following our human rights risks and impact, as well as community health assessments conducted in communities provide a concise and first-hand needs assessment. This informs our planning and implementation strategies.  Glencore engages regularly with a broad base of stakeholders including youth and women through our community engagement structures. Glencore places high value on stakeholder engagement, free prior and informed consent and ensures that all relevant stakeholders are continually engaged to ensure the sustainability of our operations and the communities we operate in.   Our quarterly Mayoral Stakeholder Committee meetings provide progress on SLP implementation, local enterprise and supplier development and general corporate social responsibility initiatives.         Page 4  Yours sincerely, Glencore Operations South Africa Pty Ltd    Conroy van der Westhuizen Chief Corporate Social Responsibility Officer

response_text:
Mercedes-Benz Group AG | Mercedesstraße 120 | 70372 Stuttgart       

14th July 2025 

Invitation to respond - Mercedes-Benz Group on our Weekly Update 

Dear Sir or Madam, 

Thank you for your inquiry on the Greenpeace report “Paradise Lost? How nickel mining threatens the future 
of one of the world's most important biodiversity hotspots”. 

For Mercedes-Benz, social and environmental responsibility are the pillars of responsible corporate 
governance and key factors for our long-term success. We are working to ensure that our products only 
contain raw materials and other materials that were obtained and produced without violating human rights 
and environmental standards.  

On account of the complexity of the supply chain and the variety of raw materials and other materials in our 
products, Mercedes-Benz takes a risk-based and strategic approach. To this end, we have developed a due 
diligence approach in the form of the Mercedes-Benz Human Rights Respect System. 

We use a variety of measures and concepts for the management of our supply chain. We work closely with 
our direct suppliers and oblige them to comply with our Responsible Sourcing Standards (RSS), to integrate 
them into their upstream value chains and to monitor compliance with them. .Further information with regards 
to measures taken can be found on our website and the Mercedes-Benz Sustainability Report.  

Nickel is one of the 24 raw materials that Mercedes-Benz has classified as critical, for which we carried out a 
risk-orientated raw material assessment based on the logic and methodology of the UN Guiding Principles for 
Business and Human Rights (UNGPs). The aim is to identify and mitigate risks in our raw material supply 
chains. Specific information on the methodology aligned with the UNGP can be found on our website. The 
results can be found in the Mercedes-Benz Raw Material Report – page 122. 

The assessment essentially consists of three steps: 
1. Increasing transparency along raw material supply chains – especially with regard to certain key 
components such as battery cells. To this end, Mercedes-Benz, for example, contacts the suppliers of the 
relevant components and asks them to disclose their deeper supply chain. 
2. Identification of risk hotspots in these supply chains, e.g. based on the specific risks in the individual 
mining countries. 

Mercedes-Benz Group AG | Mercedesstraße 120, 70372 Stuttgart | T +49 711 17 0 | F +49 711 17 2 22 44 | dialog@mercedes-benz.com  
group.mercedes-benz.com  

Sitz und Registergericht: Stuttgart, HRB-Nr.19360 | Vorsitzender des Aufsichtsrats: Bernd Pischetsrieder 
Vorstand: Ola Källenius, Vorsitzender; Jörg Burzer, Renata Jungo Brüngger, Sabine Kohleisen, Markus Schäfer, Britta Seeger, 
Hubertus Troska, Harald Wilhelm  

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
    
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3. Defining and implementing measures for the risk hotspots and review their long-term effectiveness. 

Based on our raw material assessment, we address environmental and human rights risks in our supply chain 
and follow them up. This includes regular dialogues with our suppliers and on-site assessments. Our clear 
goal is to make supply chains more transparent, to enable close cooperation as well as to improve a common 
understanding of local conditions. This enables us to better identify human rights and environmental risks and 
counteract them in cooperation with our suppliers. 

We currently don’t source Nickel directly. However, we map our Nickel supply chains in great detail in an 
ongoing process, as they are dynamic and very complex with many tier stages. Following our approach of 
empowerment before withdrawal, we see the strong need for a collaborative effort to mitigate against 
adverse impacts of nickel mining and processing on human rights and the environment.   

That is why we are currently in contact with other OEMs to form alliances for effective measures to protect 
human rights in the production of nickel in Indonesia in the long term. The aim is to work together on concrete 
solutions for the local people.  

Yours sincerely,

Title: Volkswagen ClimatePartner's response
Responded To: Tanzania: Maasai demand Volkswagen pull out of carbon offset scheme which allegedly violates their rights and threatens to wreck their livelihoods; Volkswagen responded
Tags: Cultural Rights|Economic, Social, and Cultural Rights|Free, prior & informed consent|Impacts on Livelihoods|Land Rights
story_text: Tanzania: Maasai demand Volkswagen pull out of carbon offset scheme which allegedly violates their rights and threatens to wreck their livelihoods; Volkswagen responded
response_text:
Volkswagen ClimatePartner response to a report published by the Maasai International 
Solidarity Alliance 

Volkswagen  ClimatePartner  takes  seriously  the  concerns  raised  in  the  report  published  by  the 
Maasai  International  Solidarity  Alliance  (MISA)  in  March  2025  regarding  soil  carbon  credit 
projects in Northern Tanzania. 
We deeply respect the history, resilience, and challenges of the Maasai people. Our involvement 
in the Longido and Monduli Rangelands Carbon Project (LMRCP), implemented by our project 
partners  Soils  for  the  Future  Tanzania  (SftFTZ,  the  project  implementing  entity)  and 
CarbonSolve  LLC,  is  grounded  in  a  commitment  to  improving  rangeland  health,  supporting 
Maasai  livelihoods,  and  promoting  climate  resilience  through  carbon  finance.  The  project  is 
designed  to  balance  traditional  pastoralist  land  use  with  sustainable  land  management  while 
ensuring  that  Maasai  communities  retain  full  control  over  their  land  and  benefit  from 
participation. 
In  the  following  section,  we  would  like  to  clarify  several  key  points  in  response  to  the  claims 
made in the MISA report: 
1. Land Ownership and Rights 

  SftFTZ does not acquire or control any land within the project area. All land titles remain 
entirely under the ownership of the Maasai villages, in accordance with Tanzanian law. 
  The project  does not  involve land sales, leases, encumbrances or transfers to  foreign or 

Tanzanian entities or individuals. 

  Maasai  communities  will  continue  to  exercise  full  rights  over  their  land  and  maintain 

their traditional grazing practices. 

2. Contract Duration and Flexibility 

  There is a scientific consensus that soil restoration takes time. The 40-year duration of the 
project contracts is needed to support the reality that degraded grasslands, such as those 
in Northern Tanzania, can take several decades to recover. 

  This  long-term  commitment  ensures  sustainable  land  regeneration  and  stable  economic 
benefits  for  communities.  The  project  agreements  can  be  reviewed  to  reflect  on 
experience with implementation. If one side does not meet its core obligations, the other 
side has the right to terminate the agreement through a defined process. 

3. Free, Prior, and Informed Consent (FPIC) Process 

  Volkswagen  ClimatePartner  places  a  strong  emphasis  on  FPIC,  ensuring  that  all 
participating communities fully understand the project’s terms, benefits, and implications. 
  The FPIC process begins with an early engagement to introduce the project, explain its 
broad  concepts  and  its  progression  from  introduction  to  implementation.  This  process 
includes,  initially,  the  Memorandum  of  Understanding  (MoU)  and  results  in  the  two 
project  agreements,  namely  the  Carbon  Rights  Assignment  Agreement  and  the  Benefit 
Sharing Agreement. 

  Engagement  includes  women,  youth,  and  village  elders,  with  all  agreements  requiring 

final approval from the village assembly before implementation. 

  Dedicated  Maasai  team  members  within  SftFTZ  lead  consultations  to  ensure  cultural 

sensitivity, inclusivity, and transparency. 

  An  independent  data  management  consultancy  tracks  all  FPIC-related  activities  to 

document engagement and ensure full transparency. 

4. Pastoralist Traditions and Grazing Practices 

  The project is not designed to restrict Maasai traditions but rather to support sustainable 

pastoralism by preventing overgrazing and land degradation. 

  The  project  does  not  disrupt  traditional  grazing  but  rather  supports  it  with  financial 
benefits, ensuring its sustainability while focusing specifically on preventing overgrazing. 

 Volkswagen ClimatePartner response to a report published by the Maasai International 
Solidarity Alliance 

  The  project  ensures  flexible  yet  secure  governance  of  grazing  activities.  While  villages 
commit  to  core  grazing  principles,  each  village  grazing  committee  designs  a  specific 
management plan that is agreed upon by participants. This plan can be adjusted over time 
to respond to changing conditions, emergencies, and community needs. 

5. Fair Benefit-Sharing Mechanism and Initial Project Payments 

  The  project  follows  the  Tanzanian  legal  framework  on  carbon  trading,  ensuring  that 

revenues are distributed fairly among stakeholders. 

  Benefit  sharing  is  guided  by  the  Tanzanian  legal  framework  as  further  negotiated 

 

between the villages and SftFTZ with oversight from the district. 
Initial project payments are used to support project preparation. The payments are made 
after  the  Benefit  Sharing  Agreements  have  been  signed  and  after  the  Rapid  Rotational 
Grazing Plans have been developed. 

6. Scientific Basis and Environmental Impact 

  There is a broad consensus among the scientific community and global institutions, such 
as  the  Intergovernmental  Panel  on  Climate  Change  (IPCC),  that  tackling  soil  and  land 
degradation—including  soil  carbon  enhancements—is  vital  for  combating  climate 
change. Carbon crediting serves as an additional tool to achieve these impacts. 

  The  project  methodology  applies  a  peer-reviewed  soil  carbon  model,  which  has  been 
approved by VERRA for use in relevant contexts, including arid and semi-arid regions of 
East Africa. 

  The methodology requires ex-post soil sampling to determine the actual accumulation of 

soil carbon over time to avoid over-crediting. 

Volkswagen  ClimatePartner  is  committed  to  ensuring  that  our  climate  initiatives  respect  land 
rights,  promote  sustainable  development,  and  create  real  benefits  for  communities.  We  are 
committed  to  ongoing  engagement  with  Maasai  communities,  independent  experts,  and 
regulatory bodies. 

For further inquiries, please contact: 
Volkswagen ClimatePartner 
communications@volkswagen-climatepartner.de

况  。我们对此高度重视，并第一时间开展核实。经查，相关报道内容与事实严

重不符。现就有关情况郑重澄清如下： 

      穆索诺伊为员工提供具有竞争力的薪酬待遇，整体高于当地行业平均水平。

穆索诺伊持续落实公平合理的薪酬调整机制，提供完善的医疗保障等福利安排。

会举办了五一国际劳动节庆祝活动，进一步增强了员工的归属感与凝聚力。 

      穆索诺伊始终坚持“生命至上、安全第一”的理念，严格遵守所在国法律法规，

持续强化职业健康与安全保障。我们为员工配备符合标准的劳动防护装备，确保

具备安全意识与风险管控能力。 

        我们再次重申，“共同发展、共享发展”始终是我们坚持的核心价值观。我们

将持续关注和保障员工的基本权益，同时也愿意与政府及各利益相关方保持沟通，

 开展坦诚、建设性的交流与合作，共同推动企业与社会的可持续发展。 

Recently, certain media outlets have published reports concerning our company’s treatment of 
workers, freedom of association and safety protections. Commus takes these reports extremely 
seriously and immediately launched a thorough verification. Our investigation shows that the 
content of these reports is seriously inconsistent with the facts. We hereby clarify as follows: 

Commus offers competitive remuneration that exceeds the local industry average. We maintain 
a fair and transparent salary-review mechanism and provide comprehensive medical coverage. 
Since 2024 we have significantly increased education subsidies for employees’ children, further 
enhancing family welfare.   

Commus is committed to safeguarding fundamental labour rights. We fully respect employees’ 
legal right to form and join trade unions voluntarily, and we engage in constructive dialogue 
with  both  internal  and  external  unions. A  consultative  meeting  with  elected  internal  union 
representatives is held on the last Saturday of every month. A joint quarterly meeting with all 
internal and external unions reviews key labour-relations issues and tracks the implementation 
of agreed improvements. Employees are encouraged to participate in union activities, fostering 
a culture of solidarity and shared progress. On 1 May 2025 Commus and the unions jointly 
celebrated  International  Workers’  Day,  strengthening  employees’  sense  of  belonging  and 
cohesion. Guided by the principle “Life first, safety always,”   

Commus strictly complies with national laws and continuously strengthens health and safety 
management.  All  employees  receive  and  are  required  to  use  standard-compliant  personal 
protective equipment; the rule is “No PPE, no work.” Mandatory safety-training programmes 
ensure workers understand operational risks, safe practices and emergency procedures, building 
both awareness and risk-control capacity.   

“Joint development and shared prosperity” remain our core values. We will continue to protect 
employees’ fundamental rights and maintain open, constructive dialogue with governments and 
all stakeholders to advance sustainable development for both the company and society.

Title: Nestlé response re- allegations of migrant worker rights abuses at palm oil plantations in Malaysia
Responded To: Malaysia: Indonesian workers on palm oil plantations allegedly supplying multinational brands report rights violations, incl. poverty wages, gender discrimination & precarious conditions, incl. cos. responses & non-response
story_text: Malaysia: Indonesian workers on palm oil plantations allegedly supplying multinational brands report rights violations, incl. poverty wages, gender discrimination & precarious conditions; incl. cos. responses & non-response - Business & Human Rights Resource Centre
response_text:
Invitation to respond – Report published by Migran Berdaulat 

Nestlé’s response as of 7 August 2025 

Dear Business and Human Rights Resource Center, 

Rest  assured  that  we  take  these  allegations  very  seriously  and  have  engaged  with  our 
direct suppliers as well Solidar Suisse on the general findings. At Nestlé, we share your 
ambition to advance and improve human rights across our value chain.  

People and respect for human rights are at the heart of our culture and values and one of 
our Corporate Business Principles. We are committed to upholding human rights across 
our operations and supply chain, and our Human Rights Framework and Roadmap guides 
us in our due diligence approach - assessing, addressing, and reporting transparently on 
actual  and  potential  human  rights  risks.  At  Nestlé,  we  apply  stringent  due  diligence 
processes throughout our value chain, and our direct suppliers must fully comply with all 
local  laws,  international  standards,  and  applicable  regulations,  and  adhere  to  our 
Responsible Sourcing Core Requirements. 

In February 2023, we published dedicated action plans to help us enhance human rights 
due diligence across our value chain and in priority countries where we operate and/or 
source from. We report on this area of our work in our Creating Shared Value report and 
Non-Financial Statement, published annually on our website.  

We recognize the deep systemic problems in the palm oil sector and are committed to 
working with all stakeholders to help ensure the palm oil we buy is responsibly sourced. 
Since 2021, we have implemented a specific Palm Oil Human Rights Action Plan with our 
direct suppliers and NGOs to help us better assess, address and publicly report on labor 
rights risks in our palm oil supply chain. Last year, we furthered this work by rolling out 
Human  Rights  Action  Plans  nationwide  in  Malaysia,  Indonesia  and  Colombia.  These 
national-level plans enable us to identify and understand the most salient human rights 
risks  in  specific  palm  oil  production  areas,  in  turn  informing  any  actions  that  may  be 
needed.  These  actions  are  both  at  a  direct  supplier-level  and  beyond  (i.e.,  further 
upstream in our supply chain), through collaborative activity at national level (for example 
landscape or sectoral initiatives).  

For the last six years, Nestlé has supported palm oil supplier SD Guthrie (formerly Sime 
Darby)  with  funding  for  Suara  Kami,  an  independent  grievance  mechanism  helpline 
administered and socialized by LRQA. SD Guthrie employees can report grievances to 
Suara  Kami  through  the  hotline  phone  number,  WhatsApp,  and  Facebook  Messenger. 
LRQA staffs Suara Kami with operators who log workers’ grievances in eight languages 
(Bahasa  Indonesian,  Bengali,  Burmese,  English,  Hindi,  Malay,  Nepalese,  and  Tamil), 
categorizing the grievances by site, type of grievance, and risk level. LRQA coordinates 
anonymized  grievance  response  with  a  dedicated  team  at  Suara  Kami  and  provides 
Nestlé with reports on the status of the grievances. The successes of this independent 

 
 
 
 
 
 grievance mechanism are replicable and—as of 2023— LRQA has rolled out Suara Kami 
to  other  palm  oil  companies  including  FGV  and  began  implementing  with  a  glove 
manufacturer in Malaysia.   

Regarding Malaysia specifically, we conducted a human rights risk assessment and root 
cause analysis to identify priority issues to be addressed through  the 2025-28 Human 
Rights  Action  Plan  in  Sabah,  Sarawak  and  on  the  Malaysian  peninsula.  In  Sabah,  our 
focus remains on addressing child labor risk, a systemic issue with multiple root causes 
that requires us to look into local wages and working conditions. We also work with our 
direct suppliers to continuously improve sustainability practices in our upstream supply 
chain. This helps inform the development of action plans with clear deadlines to act upon 
salient risks and identify opportunities for improvement. 

In addition to the above actions, Nestlé Malaysia has also entered into a partnership with 
the  Malaysian  Sustainable  Palm  Oil  (MSPO)  Certification  Scheme.  The  MoU  sets  the 
stage  for  technical  knowledge  exchange,  capacity-building  initiatives,  and  efforts  to 
improve  traceability  and  smallholder  certification  readiness.  Initial  areas  of  focus  will 
include supply chain mapping and training support — laying the groundwork for broader 
alignment  with  global  sustainability  requirements,  including  the  EU  Deforestation 
Regulation (EUDR).  

The  MoU  also  serves  as  a  precursor  to  the  MSPO  Impact  Alliance  —  a  new  multi-
stakeholder  platform  designed  to  explore  and  test  innovative  models  that  extend  the 
value of certification. Through collaboration with NGOs, financiers, technology partners, 
and multinational FMCG companies, the Alliance will enable MSPO to pilot ideas such 
as green financing for certified producers, digitised traceability solutions, deforestation 
monitoring tools, and inclusive sourcing incentives for smallholders. Nestlé Malaysia will 
join  as  a  founding  member,  contributing  to  shared  learning  and  collaborative 
implementation that will inform MSPO’s next phase of impact. 

With respect to human rights and environmental due diligence (HREDD), Nestlé, together 
with our technical partner, Proforest, engages priority Tier 1 palm oil suppliers (covering 
80% of our palm oil volumes) to ensure they have adequate HREDD systems in place and 
to  support  them  in  their  continuous  improvement  journey.  The  first  steps  of  the 
engagement process involve assessing suppliers’ HREDD maturity level, followed by the 
development of scorecards with recommendations for improvement. Suppliers are then 
expected to develop action plans to address identified gaps while being supported with 
guidance  and  capacity-building.  Their  progress  is  monitored  and  annually  reported  to 
ensure continuous improvement. We are also working with key suppliers on action plans 
for  prioritized  origin  refineries  to  effectively  address  risks  and  issues  at  the  origin 
level. This includes our most important direct suppliers for Sabah. 

We  work  with  the  non-profit  organization,  Winrock  International,  that  manages  the 
Nestlé Human Rights Fund. Through the Fund, Nestlé provides targeted co-funding to our 
direct palm oil suppliers through human rights grants to implement specific projects in 
Southeast Asia, West Africa, and  Latin America. A cornerstone of the Fund is supplier 
support through the Earthworm Foundation’s Labour Transformation Programme (LTP). 
The  LTP  is  an  on-site  engagement  effort  with  mills  and  plantations  in  the  Nestlé  palm 
supply  chain  to  identify  and  address  potential  human  rights  risks.  The  Earthworm 

 Foundation conducts extensive document reviews and interviews with management and 
workers  to  measure  compliance  with  local,  national,  and  international  human  rights 
standards and laws, including those concerning:  

•  Wages and time management (wage amount and deductions, wage transparency 
and pay slip management, and working hours, overtime and rest management)  
•  Accommodation (location, structure and size, and equipment and safety features)  
•  Health and safety  
•  Grievance Management 
•  Employment contract 
•  Freedom  of  movement  (access  to  identity  documents  to  facilitate  workers 

movement outside the mill and plantation) 

Each mill and plantation receive a personalized action plan and resources to remedy any 
potential human rights risks, which the Earthworm Foundation monitor and discuss the 
progress made during follow-up visits.  

Finally, since the publication of the report, representatives from Nestlé HQ and Nestlé 
Malaysia have visited suppliers in Sabah to get a first-hand understanding of the situation 
on-ground. They also met with representatives of human rights organizations to find ways 
to address the structural issues identified in the report.  

Thanks  again  for  reaching  out  to  us,  and  for  requesting  our  feedback  on  the  Migran 
Berdaulat report. These are critical and challenging issues requiring broad-based, multi-
stakeholder solutions. We hope that we can work together to chart a path forward that 
helps improve livelihoods in Sabah, Malaysia.

story_text: Indonesia: Human rights and environmental abuses linked to nickel mining in Halmahera continue to be exposed by Climate Rights International; incl. cos. responses and non-responses - Business & Human Rights Resource Centre
response_text:
Thank you for the opportunity  to respond  to the follow-up report  by Climate Rights International  (CRI). We 
know  that  some entities in our extended  supply chain for electric vehicle production  are  sourcing nickel from 
Indonesia.  As part  of our focus on human  rights, our measures  align with the  recommendations  cited in the 
CRI report. 

• 

Leverage  buying power  to pressure  mines and/or  suppliers to change  practices  that  cause severe 
damage  to the climate system and  environmental  or human  rights harm,  and if necessary, stop 
sourcing nickel from producers  engaged  in human  rights and environmental  violations.  

We work to inform our decisions with transparent  due  diligence and supply chain mapping.  Our due diligence 
framework  is anchored  in the OECD Guidelines for Multinational  Enterprises,  the UN Guiding Principles on 
Business and  Human Rights, and ILO core conventions,  to verify ethical practices  and identify risks 
proactively. 

Also, when reasonably  possible, we engage  in vertical integration  and direct  sourcing of critical raw  materials 
(e.g., lithium, nickel, cobalt) to promote  greater  visibility, transparency,  and alignment  with sustainability 
principles throughout  our supply chain. We conduct  country and supplier-level  ESG risk assessments, 
drawing  from reputable  external  sources—including  CAHRAs, the World Bank, and the Heidelberg  Report—
to evaluate  environmental,  social, and governance  exposures. 

If  material  ESG  gaps  in  the  supply  chain  are  identified  and  not  adequately  addressed  through  corrective 
action,  we  will  take  appropriate  measures,  including  potential  termination  of  business  relationships with our 
immediate  suppliers  and/or  other  measures  designed  to  apply  legitimate  leverage on the supply chain actors. 
This  strategy  promotes  responsible  development  of  upstream  industries  and  fosters  long-term  partnerships 
that  reflect  our  shared  commitment  to  sustainability.  We  value  working  with  partners  who  share  our 
commitment  to responsible  sourcing and uphold  the principles that  guide us. 

• 

Leverage  buying power  to pressure  mines and/or  suppliers to provide publicly available information 
on water  and air quality in the areas  surrounding  their operations,  as well as an accurate  account  of 
greenhouse  gas emissions resulting  from the use of coal to power  IWIP operations.  

Stellantis’  Global Responsible Purchasing  Guidelines (GRPG) detail our overall supplier expectations  in 
relation  to human  rights. Stellantis  seeks increased  transparency  regarding  Environmental,  Social and 
Governance  topics from our value chain  because  we recognize  and respect  the fundamental  human  right to 
clean air, clean water  and environmental  preservation.  To underline  these  expectations  our  contracted/Tier  1 
suppliers are asked  to sign the  GRPG to confirm their  commitment. Our Environment  and Energy 
commitments  establish the framework  for setting  internal  objectives  and targets,  that  seek to minimize the 
environmental  impact of our business on current  and future  generations,  communities  and resources.  

•  Require  direct  suppliers to disclose their full list of suppliers, as well as documentation  that  direct 
suppliers are implementing  EV company policies on human  rights, environmental  and climate due 
diligence with their  suppliers, and  make that  information  about EV supply chains publicly available 
and accessible. 

We do require  specific targeted  commodities to provide us details of their supplier  list, e.g., conflict minerals 
smelter and/or  refiner  lists, but obtaining  such information  is often challenging  for legal and  practical 
reasons.  For similar reasons we do not publicly disclose the identities of the  individual supplier  information 
we are able to obtain.  We do, however, provide  aggregated  data  and performance  metrics in our annual 
Corporate  Sustainability  Report.  We leverage  the requirements  of the European  Union  Battery  Regulation  to 
promote  transparency  in the supply chain. 

 •  Conduct  regular,  transparent,  and genuinely  independent  audits of mines and facilities where  nickel 
and other  critical minerals  are mined and refined  to ensure  that  suppliers are following procedures 
that  protect  and  respect  human rights  and Indigenous  Peoples’  rights, meet environmental 
standards,  and  don’t contribute  to climate change. 

Our supplier mitigation  strategy  includes requiring  independent  third party  ESG assessments;  mandating  ESG 
audits;  helping suppliers develop foundational  ESG policies (e.g., Codes  of Conduct);  and  maintaining 
contractual  safeguards,  including termination  rights  for non-compliance. 

On top of the previously mentioned  activities, for direct  raw material  purchases,  independent  on-site audits 
are deployed  for all critical minerals used in EV batteries  to assess mining and  refining  operations.  Identified 
findings from the audit are  analyzed  and inform time-bound  corrective action plans with ongoing  monitoring. 
Through  continuous  monitoring,  transparency,  and escalation  mechanisms, Stellantis  enforces  its ESG 
standards  and supports  alignment  with stakeholder  expectations  and regulatory  frameworks —thereby 
aiming to prevent  situations akin to those  documented  in the CRI report 

• 

Set  explicit, time-bound  targets  to decarbonize  transition  mineral  supply chains and  ensure  that 
suppliers are taking  concrete  steps to reach those  targets. 

Suppliers  are key stakeholders  of Stellantis’  approach  to reduce  CO2 scope 3 upstream  emissions, from ore 
extraction  till components  production,  focusing on emissions generated  from the production  of goods and 
services purchased  by Stellantis. Our purchasing  department  defined  a target  to increase to 95% the share of 
APV from key suppliers with CO2 reduction  targets  that  comply with the Paris Agreement  by 2030. We have 
prioritized  components  and  raw materials that  represent  80% of GHG emissions from our BEV supply chain. 
They are  specifically tracked and  followed by engineering  and  purchasing  teams to focus on reducing  the 
carbon  footprint  of suppliers providing parts  and materials  with significant GHG emissions.  

For  direct raw material  purchases,  we establish quantified  and time-bound  targets  in sourcing to advance 
toward  our 'Carbon  Net Zero' objective.  Major suppliers are requested  to share  their carbon  net zero 
roadmap  to demonstrate  their ability to support  the Stellantis  Carbon  Net Zero Targets,  and  work on an 
emission reduction  plan compliant with the  Paris Agreement.  In addition, suppliers are  asked to participate  in 
the Carbon  Disclosure Project  (“CDP”) reporting.     

Again, thank  you for giving us the  opportunity  to respond  to your inquiry.  We remain  open to further 
dialogue  at a future  date.    

Thank you,  

Rachel Kook 

Compliance  Head  – Human Rights
